paper_title: Material Conditional Does Not Capture "If-Then" Meaning
content: The symbol "→" in classical logic (material conditional) does not mean "if...then" in natural language. It merely means "not both P and not-Q" and is strictly truth-conditional, lacking the modal/entailment force of natural language conditionals.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Natural Language Conditionals Are Modal
content: "If P, then Q" in natural language means "Q follows from P" or "not-Q is incompatible with P" - a modal notion involving possibility and impossibility, not reducible to truth-functional logic.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The Paradoxes of Material Implication Are Not Genuine Paradoxes
content: The so-called "paradoxes of validity" (e.g., that a false statement entails anything) are not real paradoxes but arise from misconstruing "P→Q" as meaning "if P, then Q" when it actually only means "not (P and not-Q)".
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Relevance Logic Misguided in Approach
content: Attempts by relevance logicians (Belnap, Anderson) to create truth-conditional approximations of natural language "if...then" are misconceived, as they try to model a fundamentally modal notion using truth-conditional methods.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Classical Logic Implicitly Requires Non-Truth-Conditional Conditionals
content: Classical logic is implicitly committed to a non-truth-conditional conception of conditionality, as the Law of Non-contradiction depends on the modal notion that no statement can be compatible with its own negation.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Utilitarianism Is Self-Defeating
content: Utilitarianism undermines itself because it presupposes moral bonds and commitments (like those that make Erskin's family deserving of money) while simultaneously permitting violation of those same kinds of bonds when they conflict with utility maximization.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Kantian Ethics Implicit in the Concept of Desert
content: The concept of what people "deserve" inherently presupposes a Kantian ethical framework where people are ends-in-themselves and not mere means. Without this, the concept of desert loses meaning.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Promise-Keeping Cannot Be Overridden by Utility Calculations
content: If it is morally permissible to break one promise for the sake of greater utility, then the moral bonds that create all obligations (including those that make certain people "deserve" help) are undermined. The permission to violate commitments destroys the ground of all moral desert.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Marriage and Parenthood as Moral Commitments
content: Marriage and parenthood constitute special moral commitments that create obligations not owed to others. These commitments are of the same kind as promises and cannot be selectively enforced without contradiction.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The Greatest Good Presupposes Anti-Utilitarian Ethics
content: The utilitarian goal of "the greatest good for the greatest number" presupposes a world where people can trust each other, exercise autonomy, and not be defrauded - but this presupposes exactly the kind of non-consequentialist ethics that utilitarianism rejects.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Moral Worth of Persons Is Precondition for Any "Greater Good"
content: There cannot coherently be a "greater good" in a world where people lack inherent moral worth and can be treated as mere means. The concept of a greater good depends on people having the kind of value that prohibits treating them merely as means.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Consequentialism Generally Is Self-Undermining
content: All forms of consequentialism face the same problem as utilitarianism: they permit actions that undermine the very conditions (trust, autonomy, respect for persons) that make their goals valuable.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Sensory Perception Is Reliable
content: We can trust our senses as sources of knowledge. Skeptical arguments against sensory perception fail.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Cartesian Skepticism About Senses Can Be Refuted
content: Descartes' skeptical arguments about sensory perception and the evil demon hypothesis can be successfully refuted.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: We Have Certain Knowledge
content: Despite skeptical challenges, there are things we can know with certainty.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The Problem of Induction Has a Solution
content: Hume's problem of induction can be resolved. (Note: Kuczynski's broader work argues for a rationalist a priori solution)
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Gettier Cases Show Justification Requires Non-Accidental Connection to Truth
content: Gettier's examples demonstrate that justified true belief is insufficient for knowledge. Knowledge requires that the connection between justification and truth not be accidental.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Testimony Requires Independent Verification for Knowledge
content: For testimony-based belief to constitute knowledge, one must have independent evidence of the testifier's reliability. Testimony alone is insufficient.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: We Have Access to Absolute Truth
content: There exists such a thing as absolute truth, and we can know it. Relativism about truth is false.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Uncertainty Has Philosophical Value
content: Recognition of uncertainty and the limits of knowledge has important philosophical value (despite our ability to know some things absolutely).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Bostrom's Simulation Argument Deserves Serious Consideration
content: Nick Bostrom's argument that we may be living in a computer simulation raises genuine epistemological questions worthy of philosophical analysis.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Mind-Body Dualism Has Strong Arguments
content: There are compelling arguments for substance dualism - the view that mind and body are fundamentally different kinds of substances.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Materialism Faces the Hard Problem of Consciousness
content: Materialist accounts of mind face severe difficulties explaining subjective conscious experience (the "hard problem").
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Nagel's Argument Against Materialism Is Sound
content: Thomas Nagel's famous argument (from "What Is It Like to Be a Bat?") successfully refutes materialist theories of mind.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Subjective Experience Cannot Be Reduced to Physical Facts
content: The qualitative, subjective nature of conscious experience (qualia) cannot be fully captured or explained by physical/functional descriptions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The Explanatory Gap Is Real
content: There is a genuine explanatory gap between physical/functional descriptions of brain states and phenomenal consciousness that materialist theories cannot bridge.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Dennett's Eliminativism About Consciousness Is False
content: Daniel Dennett's attempt to eliminate or explain away phenomenal consciousness fails. Consciousness is real and cannot be explained in purely functional/behavioral terms.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Wittgenstein on Language and Thought Contains Important Insights
content: Wittgenstein's views on the relationship between language and thought raise important philosophical questions about meaning and understanding.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Referential-Attributive Distinction Is Not Russellian
content: The distinction between referential and attributive uses of descriptions requires a non-Russellian treatment. Russell's theory of descriptions cannot adequately capture this distinction.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The Hypothetico-Deductive Method Has Serious Problems
content: The hypothetico-deductive method of scientific confirmation faces significant philosophical difficulties that undermine its status as the primary method of scientific reasoning.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Values Play an Essential Role in Science
content: Value judgments are not eliminable from scientific practice. Science necessarily involves value assumptions that go beyond purely empirical matters.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Modern Science Has Distinctive Epistemic Features
content: Modern scientific method differs fundamentally from pre-modern approaches to knowledge in ways that have important philosophical implications.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Early Modern Scientific Thought Represents Philosophical Breakthrough
content: The scientific revolution of the early modern period (Galileo, Newton, etc.) represents a fundamental shift in philosophical thinking about nature and knowledge.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Moore's Proof of an External World Fails
content: G.E. Moore's famous proof of an external world (by holding up his hands) is unsuccessful and does not refute skepticism about the external world.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: There Is an External World
content: Despite problems with Moore's proof, we can establish that an external world exists.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Descartes' Conception of Self Is Defensible
content: Descartes' view of what he is (a thinking thing) can be defended, though aspects require modification.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Standard Arguments for God's Existence Fail
content: The traditional arguments for God's existence (cosmological, teleological, ontological) are unsuccessful.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: There Are Genuine Paradoxes Relating to God
content: The concept of God as traditionally understood generates genuine paradoxes (e.g., omnipotence paradox, problem of evil) that create serious philosophical difficulties.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: God Is Not Necessary for Morality
content: Morality does not depend on God's existence. Ethical truths and obligations exist independently of whether God exists.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: God's Foreknowledge Conflicts with Moral Responsibility
content: If God has complete foreknowledge of all future events, human beings cannot be genuinely morally responsible for their actions. Divine foreknowledge and human free will are incompatible.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Agnosticism Is More Defensible Than Theism
content: Given the arguments for and against God's existence, agnosticism is a more philosophically defensible position than belief in God.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Religious Institutions Face a Fundamental Paradox
content: Religious institutions face an inherent paradox in attempting to systematize and institutionalize what is supposed to be a matter of personal faith and individual spiritual experience.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Clifford Right About Epistemic Duty, William James Wrong
content: W.K. Clifford's view that it is wrong to believe anything on insufficient evidence is correct, while William James' defense of the "will to believe" in religious matters is misguided.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Dawkins' Critique of Religion Has Merit But Also Problems
content: Richard Dawkins' arguments against religion contain valuable criticisms but also exhibit philosophical weaknesses.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Wollstonecraft and Marx Correct About Religion's Social Function
content: Mary Wollstonecraft and Karl Marx were right that religion serves problematic social functions, though their views differ in details.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Galileo Was Right to Challenge Religious Authority on Scientific Matters
content: Galileo was justified in asserting the autonomy of scientific investigation against religious authority.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Searle's Chinese Room Refutes Strong AI
content: John Searle's Chinese Room argument successfully demonstrates that mere computation/symbol manipulation is insufficient for genuine understanding and consciousness.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Turing Test Is Not a Good Test of Intelligence
content: The Turing Test (Imitation Game) is not an adequate test for genuine intelligence or consciousness. Behavioral indistinguishability from humans does not establish presence of mind.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Free Will Is Compatible with Determinism
content: Free will and determinism are compatible (compatibilism). We can act freely even if our actions are determined by prior causes.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Hume, Frankfurt, and Holbach on Freedom Raise Important Issues
content: The views of Hume, Harry Frankfurt, and Baron d'Holbach on personal freedom and responsibility raise important questions about the nature of human agency.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Neuroscience Does Not Eliminate Free Will
content: Recent neuroscientific findings (e.g., Libet experiments) do not actually disprove the existence of free will.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Operant Conditioning Does Not Disprove Free Will
content: The existence of operant conditioning and behavioral modification does not establish that we lack free will.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Consciousness and Free Will Are Compatible
content: There is no conflict between the phenomenology of consciousness and the existence of free will.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: We Have Access to Our Own Mental States Through Introspection
content: We have privileged first-person access to our own mental states through introspection. This access is direct and generally reliable.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Apes Lack Key Cognitive Capacities Humans Possess
content: Despite significant cognitive abilities in great apes, humans possess distinctive cognitive capacities (likely related to language and abstract thought) that apes lack.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Mill's Harm Principle Defensible
content: John Stuart Mill's harm principle (that liberty should only be restricted to prevent harm to others) is fundamentally sound.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Liberty Has Intrinsic Value
content: Personal freedom and liberty have inherent value, not merely instrumental value for producing other goods.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Hobbes, Marx, Rousseau, Nietzsche Each Identify Central Problems
content: Hobbes' analysis of the state of nature, Marx's critique of capitalism, Rousseau's social contract theory, and Nietzsche's critique of conventional morality each identify important truths about politics and society.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Free Markets Have Both Virtues and Vices
content: Free market systems produce important benefits (efficiency, innovation, wealth creation) but also generate serious problems (inequality, exploitation, market failures).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Legal Freedom and Substantive Freedom Can Conflict
content: There is a tension between legal/formal freedom (absence of coercion) and substantive freedom (actual ability to pursue one's goals). The free market can maximize the former while limiting the latter.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Mill and von Hayek Make Important Contributions to Economic Philosophy
content: Both Mill's and Friedrich von Hayek's analyses of free market economics contain valuable insights, despite their different emphases.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Founding Fathers Had Complex Views on Democracy
content: The American founding fathers both supported and opposed democratic elements. The Constitution was neither simply democratic nor simply anti-democratic but mixed.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Plato's Republic Prefigures Totalitarianism
content: Plato's ideal state in the Republic shares disturbing features with modern totalitarian regimes (echoing Karl Popper's famous critique).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Freedom of Speech Has Limits
content: While freedom of speech is valuable and important, it is not absolute. There are legitimate limits to free expression.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Freedom of Speech Deserves Strong Defense
content: Despite legitimate limits, freedom of speech requires robust defense against attempts to restrict it for bad reasons.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Prejudice Functions as Psychological Resistance
content: Prejudice and bigotry serve psychological functions (such as maintaining self-esteem, creating in-group solidarity, projecting unacceptable impulses onto out-groups).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Freudian Analysis Illuminates Prejudice
content: Psychoanalytic concepts (sublimation, projection, displacement) help explain the psychological roots of prejudice and discrimination.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: College Admissions Should Consider Standardized Tests
content: Standardized tests should continue to play a role in college admissions despite their limitations, as they provide valuable information about academic preparation.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Wealth Redistribution Can Be Legitimate
content: Under certain conditions, government redistribution of wealth is morally justified.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Drug Legalization Has Economic Justification
content: There are strong economic arguments for legalizing currently prohibited drugs.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Environmental Regulation Preferable to Carbon Taxes
content: Direct environmental regulations are superior to carbon tax schemes for addressing environmental problems.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Minimum Wage Laws Are Economically Harmful
content: Minimum wage laws, despite good intentions, produce negative economic consequences that harm those they intend to help.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: American Entry into WWI Had Economic Justification
content: The United States' entry into World War I can be justified on economic grounds.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: US Was a World Leader 1946-1991
content: The United States functioned as a genuine world leader during the Cold War period, despite problematic aspects of its foreign policy.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Colonialism Differs from Imperialism
content: Colonialism and imperialism, while related, are distinct phenomena that need to be analyzed separately.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Soviet Union Collapse Had Multiple Causes
content: The collapse of the Soviet Union resulted from a combination of economic, political, and social factors rather than any single cause.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Late-Term Abortions Raise Serious Ethical Issues
content: Late-term abortions present more difficult ethical questions than early-term abortions, requiring careful philosophical analysis.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Suicide Raises Complex Philosophical Questions
content: Schopenhauer's analysis of suicide and related philosophical discussions show that the ethics of suicide is more complex than commonly assumed.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Corporate Executives Should Be Held Criminally Liable for Workplace Deaths
content: When corporate negligence leads to deaths or injuries in the workplace, executives should face criminal rather than merely civil penalties.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Euthanasia and Medical Ethics Require Careful Analysis
content: End-of-life medical decisions, including euthanasia, raise complex ethical issues that demand rigorous philosophical examination.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Business Ethics Faces "Endgame" Scenarios
content: Business people regularly face ethical dilemmas where maintaining ethical principles seems to conflict with competitive success, requiring philosophical analysis of whether ethics and business success are compatible.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Camus and Schopenhauer Share Views on Meaning of Life
content: Albert Camus and Arthur Schopenhauer reach similar conclusions about the meaninglessness or absurdity of life, despite different philosophical frameworks.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Camus and Nagel on Life's Meaning Converge
content: Camus' absurdism and Thomas Nagel's analysis of life's meaning share important insights about the human condition.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Camus' Hero Is Rebel Without Traditional Cause
content: Camus' vision of authentic existence involves rebellion against absurdity without appeal to traditional religious or metaphysical meaning.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Schopenhauer on Human Suffering Remains Relevant
content: Schopenhauer's analysis of human suffering and the will contains insights that remain philosophically important.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Schopenhauer's Metaphysics Has Fractal Structure
content: Schopenhauer's conception of reality involves a fractal-like structure where the same patterns repeat at different levels.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Nietzsche and Schopenhauer on Meaning Differ Importantly
content: While both Nietzsche and Schopenhauer deny traditional religious meaning, their alternative visions differ significantly.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Sartre's Later Work Inferior to Earlier Work
content: Sartre's later Marxist writings are philosophically weaker than his earlier existentialist work.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Socrates' Execution Involved Multiple Factors
content: Socrates was executed not simply for his philosophical views but due to a complex combination of political, social, and philosophical factors.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Pre-Socratics Identify Problem of the One and the Many
content: The pre-Socratic philosophers identified a fundamental metaphysical problem about unity and plurality that remains important.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Plato's Cave Allegory Addresses Epistemology and Metaphysics
content: Plato's allegory of the cave makes important points about both the nature of knowledge and the structure of reality.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Aristotle's Virtue Ethics Has Enduring Value
content: Aristotle's approach to ethics through virtue and character development provides an important alternative to consequentialism and deontology.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Aristotle's Conception of Good Life Remains Relevant
content: Aristotle's analysis of eudaimonia (flourishing/the good life) offers insights applicable to contemporary questions about wellbeing.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Aristotle on Virtue More Defensible Than Kant
content: Aristotle's virtue-based approach to ethics is philosophically superior to Kant's duty-based approach in important respects.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Kant's Moral Philosophy Has Significant Strengths
content: Kant's ethical theory, based on the categorical imperative and treating persons as ends, captures important moral truths.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Kant's Formula of Humanity Captures Core of Morality
content: Kant's principle of treating humanity always as an end and never merely as a means expresses a fundamental moral truth.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Locke, Aristotle, and Kant on Virtue Can Be Synthesized
content: The virtue theories of Locke, Aristotle, and Kant can be partially integrated despite their differences.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Bentham and Mill on Pleasure Differ Importantly
content: Jeremy Bentham's quantitative hedonism and John Stuart Mill's qualitative hedonism represent significantly different approaches to utilitarian ethics.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Mill vs. Hobbes on Liberty Reveals Deep Disagreement
content: Mill's defense of liberty and Hobbes' more restricted view of freedom reflect fundamentally different conceptions of human nature and politics.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Rousseau, Goldman, and von Hayek Offer Competing Views of Ideal State
content: Different political philosophers (Rousseau's general will, Emma Goldman's anarchism, Hayek's spontaneous order) present competing but each partially valid visions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Sociology of Knowledge Has Philosophical Importance
content: Sociological factors in knowledge production raise important epistemological questions about objectivity and justification.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Cartesian Certainty Possible But Limited
content: We can achieve the kind of certainty Descartes sought, but only for a limited range of propositions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: There Are Things We Know with Certainty
content: Despite skeptical challenges, there are propositions we can know with absolute certainty (e.g., "I exist," "I am thinking").
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Global Warming Evidence Is Compelling
content: The scientific evidence for anthropogenic climate change is strong enough to warrant serious concern and policy responses.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Evolution Is Well-Established Scientific Fact
content: The theory of evolution by natural selection is supported by overwhelming evidence and is as well-established as any scientific theory.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Fiction Has Important Purpose
content: Fictional narratives serve important functions beyond mere entertainment, including moral education, emotional development, and exploring possibilities.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Modern Art Raises Philosophical Questions
content: Works of modern art raise important philosophical questions about the nature of art, beauty, and aesthetic value.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Language and Thought Are Intimately Connected
content: Language and thought are deeply interconnected, though the exact nature of their relationship requires careful analysis.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Intensionality and Modality Raise Pre-Semantic Issues
content: Questions about intensional contexts and modal operators raise important pre-semantic considerations about meaning.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Higher Education Has Distinctive Business Model
content: Universities operate according to a distinctive business model that differs fundamentally from ordinary commercial enterprises.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Graduation and Retention Rates May Not Matter Most
content: Contrary to common assumptions, graduation and retention rates may not be the most important metrics for evaluating educational institutions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Universities Sell Degrees, Not Instruction
content: The fundamental product universities offer is credentials (degrees) rather than education or instruction per se.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge Management Principles Don't Apply to Traditional Universities
content: Standard knowledge management principles used in business cannot be straightforwardly applied to traditional university structures.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Digitization of Education Often Advisable
content: Many forms of education can and should be digitized when possible for efficiency and accessibility.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Alternative Education Models Should Be Explored
content: Alternative models of higher education (like the hypothetical "DMO" described) deserve serious consideration as improvements over traditional university structures.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Education Should Emphasize Instruction Over Selection
content: Educational institutions should focus more on providing quality instruction to students than on functioning as gatekeepers selecting the most talented.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Consequentialism Self-Defeating Generally
content: The critique of utilitarianism extends to all forms of consequentialism: they undermine the conditions that make their goals valuable.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Deontological Constraints Are Rationally Required
content: Deontological constraints (such as prohibitions on treating persons as mere means) are not arbitrary restrictions on utility maximization but rational requirements of coherent moral thinking.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Moral Bonds and Commitments Foundational
content: Relationships involving trust, commitment, and special obligations (friendship, family, promises) are foundational to morality rather than being overrideable by impersonal utility calculations.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Good Employee Treatment Not Always Profitable
content: While treating employees well can sometimes increase profitability, there are cases where ethical treatment of workers reduces short-term profits, creating genuine ethical dilemmas for businesses.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Corporate Social Responsibility More Than Profit Maximization
content: Contra Milton Friedman, the social responsibility of business extends beyond mere profit maximization to stakeholders beyond shareholders.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Money Can Function Like a Drug
content: The pursuit of money can exhibit addiction-like psychological patterns that raise ethical questions about capitalism and human motivation.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Parable of the Sadhu Reveals Ethical Failures
content: The famous business ethics case "Parable of the Sadhu" reveals how people can fail to act ethically in group situations even when they would act ethically individually.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Sublimation Remains Relevant Concept
content: Freud's concept of sublimation (redirecting instinctual energy into socially acceptable outlets) remains psychologically and philosophically relevant.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Failure to Sublimate Explains Some Pathologies
content: The "Peter Pan syndrome" and related psychological patterns can be understood as failures of proper sublimation of impulses.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Attachment Theory Illuminates Mental Illness
content: Attachment theory provides important insights into the development and nature of various mental illnesses.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Evolutionary Psychology Explains Why We Lie
content: Lying and deception have evolutionary explanations related to adaptive strategies in social competition and cooperation.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Internal vs. External Motivation Distinction Important
content: The distinction between intrinsic and extrinsic motivation has important implications for psychology, education, and workplace management.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Prejudice Has Deep Psychological Roots
content: Prejudice and discrimination are not mere ignorance but have deep psychological roots in ego defense mechanisms and social identity formation.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Feminist Theory Identifies Patriarchal Structures
content: Feminist analysis successfully identifies systematic patterns of male dominance in social structures.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Critical Thinking Faces Systematic Traps
content: There are identifiable patterns of fallacious reasoning that systematically impede critical thinking and rational discourse.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Free Market Creates Contradictions
content: Free market capitalism generates internal contradictions that create economic instability and social problems.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Marxist Economics Has Valid Insights
content: Despite problems with Marxist political programs, Marxist economic analysis identifies real features of capitalism.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Commodity Fetishism Is Real Phenomenon
content: Marx's concept of commodity fetishism (treating social relations as relations between things) captures a real feature of market economies.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge Capital Deserves Recognition
content: Knowledge and information should be recognized as forms of capital deserving economic analysis.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Technology-Caused Job Shortages May Require Welfare State
content: If technology produces structural unemployment, universal welfare programs may become economically necessary.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Philosophy Has Value Beyond Practical Application
content: Philosophy is valuable not primarily for practical applications but for expanding understanding, reducing dogmatism, and exploring possibilities.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Philosophical Uncertainty Has Value
content: Recognition of the limits of our knowledge and the value of uncertainty is itself an important philosophical insight.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Graduate-Level Philosophy Examines More Complex Issues
content: Graduate philosophical work differs from undergraduate work in depth, complexity, and rigor of analysis rather than just in subject matter.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Wittgenstein's Private Language Argument Is Flawed
content: Wittgenstein's argument against private language fails because private rules can have enforcement mechanisms through natural consequences (e.g., eating poisonous berries if one misinterprets one's own code), not just social enforcement.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Thought Not Inherently Linguistic
content: Thought is not inherently linguistic. There exists visual thought, musical thought, and other non-linguistic forms of thinking. Wittgenstein was wrong to identify thought with language use.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Thought Required for Language Understanding
content: Thought is logically prior to language understanding. One must be able to think in order to understand or operate with semantic rules. Therefore, thought cannot be constituted by linguistic rule-following.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Wittgenstein's Rule-Following Argument Fails
content: The rule-following argument (that all genuine rules must be social/public) is false because private rules can have real consequences that constitute genuine enforcement without social mechanisms.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Late-Term Abortions Specifically Are Unethical
content: Late-term (third trimester) abortions are ethically wrong because neurobiological evidence shows late-term fetuses have psychological characteristics similar to newborn infants, making them persons with rights.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Personhood Depends on Psychological Capacities
content: Whether something is a person (and thus has moral rights) depends on whether it has relevant psychological capacities such as consciousness, pain sensitivity, and other mental features.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Neurobiological Evidence Relevant to Abortion Ethics
content: Medical/neurobiological evidence about fetal development is directly relevant to and decisive for ethical questions about abortion.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: "Future Like Ours" Argument Has Force
content: Don Berkich's argument that fetuses have "a future like ours" and abortion robs them of this future provides a legitimate basis for opposition to abortion.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Moore's Proof Begs the Question
content: G.E. Moore's attempt to prove an external world by holding up his hands begs the question against the skeptic because the skeptic would not grant the existence of hands as mind-independent objects.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Question-Begging Broader Than Premise-Conclusion Identity
content: An argument begs the question not only when the conclusion is identical to a premise, but when the premises would not be granted by one's opponent or when accepting the premises requires already accepting the conclusion.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Sophisticated Beliefs Are Distillations of Lower-Level Beliefs
content: Beliefs like "there exists an external world" are sophistications or distillations of lower-level beliefs like "there exists a hand here." The fact that children have the latter without the former doesn't show independent plausibility.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Non-Question-Begging Arguments Against Skepticism Possible
content: Unlike Moore's proof, some arguments against skepticism don't beg the question, such as arguing from the existence of mental states plus causation principles to the existence of external causes of those mental states.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Nagel's Bat Argument Succeeds Against Materialism
content: Nagel's argument that complete knowledge of bat physiology would not give knowledge of what it's like to be a bat successfully refutes materialist accounts of consciousness.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Physiological Knowledge Insufficient for Psychological Knowledge
content: Complete knowledge of an organism's physical/physiological facts does not automatically give knowledge of that organism's phenomenal psychological states (what it's like to be that organism).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Intensional Fallacy Response to Nagel Fails
content: The objection that Nagel commits an intensional fallacy (like arguing water isn't H2O because one can know something is water without knowing it's H2O) fails because complete chemical knowledge gives complete knowledge of water, but complete physiological knowledge doesn't give complete knowledge of consciousness.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Psychology Not Reducible to Physiology
content: Psychology (what it's like to have certain experiences) cannot be reduced to or identified with physiology, even if they are in some sense correlated.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Schopenhauer Correct That Life Involves Suffering
content: Schopenhauer's analysis that life fundamentally involves suffering and that pleasure/happiness are unstable while pain is stable is essentially correct.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Life's Meaning Requires Some Strife
content: "Life without pain has no meaning" - some degree of adversity or challenge is necessary for life to have meaning (Schopenhauer's insight).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Acceptance of Life's Negativity Enables Its Positive Aspects
content: Both Camus and Schopenhauer agree that accepting what is negative or difficult in life is necessary for gaining what is positive from it.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Camus' Absurdism Differs from Schopenhauer's Pessimism
content: While both Camus and Schopenhauer have seemingly negative views of life, they differ fundamentally: Schopenhauer focuses on suffering, Camus on lack of pre-given meaning; and Camus sees lack of meaning as potentially liberating.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Search for Pre-Given Meaning Prevents Finding Meaning
content: Searching for what happiness or meaning consists of prevents one from being happy or living meaningfully (insight shared by Camus and Schopenhauer).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Lack of Pre-Given Meaning Enables Freedom
content: The fact that life doesn't have a pre-existing meaning is not purely negative; it allows human freedom to create meaning rather than being constrained by predetermined purposes (Camus).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Professional Ethics Violations Include Breach of Confidentiality
content: Violations of professional confidentiality (like discussing client information with others without consent) constitute serious ethical breaches regardless of motive.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Professional Relationships Create Ethical Boundaries
content: Romantic relationships between professionals and staff members can create ethical problems when they tempt violations of professional duties like confidentiality.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Private Conduct Matters When It Affects Professional Duties
content: While private conduct (like marital infidelity) may be morally problematic, it becomes professionally relevant primarily when it leads to breaches of professional responsibilities.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Gettier Successfully Refutes JTB Analysis of Knowledge
content: Edmund Gettier successfully showed that justified true belief is not sufficient for knowledge through his counterexamples.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge Requires Non-Accidental Justification-Truth Connection
content: The Gettier cases show that knowledge requires the connection between justification and truth to be non-accidental, not merely that both be present.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: No-False-Belief Condition Insufficient
content: The amendment that knowledge = JTB with no false beliefs in the justification chain is insufficient, as shown by Goldman's fake barn case.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Goldman's Fake Barn Shows Limits of No-False-Belief Amendment
content: In Goldman's fake barn case, Jerry has JTB based on no false beliefs but arguably lacks knowledge due to environmental luck.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge May Be Unanalyzable
content: Williamson's claim that knowledge is a primitive, unanalyzable concept may be correct given the failure of various analyses.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Assumption That All Concepts Are Analyzable Is Probably False
content: The assumption that all concepts can be analyzed in terms of more basic concepts is almost certainly false; some concepts must be primitive.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge Need Not Be Accompanied by Self-Knowledge
content: One can know something without knowing that one knows it (contra certain ordinary language analyses). Meta-knowledge involves additional concepts beyond first-order knowledge.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Radford's Knowledge-Without-Belief Claim Is Spurious
content: Radford's claim that Jean knew but didn't believe that James I died in 1625 is wrong; Jean both knew and believed but lacked meta-knowledge.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Subconscious Knowledge Counts as Belief
content: Williamson's argument succeeds: When someone "guesses" based on subconscious memory, they both believe and know, even if not consciously aware.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Bostrom's Simulation Argument Deserves Serious Consideration
content: Nick Bostrom's argument that we may be living in an ancestor simulation run by posthuman civilizations raises genuine philosophical issues.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Computational Substrate Independence Is Plausible
content: The "comp" thesis that conscious experiences can be associated with any system implementing the right computational structures is plausible and marks an important difference from mere physical processes like hurricanes.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Simulation Hypothesis Creates Epistemological Problems
content: If fsim ≈ 1 (most observers with human-type experiences are in simulations), this creates significant epistemological challenges about knowing we're not simulated.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Bostrom's "No Info" Assumption Goes Beyond What Stated
content: Bostrom's "no info" assumption that we can't distinguish simulated from biological experiences assumes more than stated - it assumes something like Byrne's skeptical premise about indistinguishability.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Experience Machine Is Bad for Multiple Reasons
content: Nozick's experience machine thought experiment shows that we value not just experiences but also actually doing things and being certain kinds of people.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Bostromian Simulation May Be Less Bad Than Experience Machine
content: Living in a Bostromian ancestor simulation might not be as bad as Nozick's experience machine, depending on whether one values being "real" in a fundamental sense.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Ethical Relativism Is False
content: Ethical relativism (that what's ethical depends on culture) is false; there are universal moral truths that transcend cultural variation.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Informed Consent Has Universal Value
content: The principle of informed consent (patients must have relevant information to make medical decisions) has universal validity across cultures.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Cultural Practices Must Be Evaluated by Universal Standards
content: When cultural practices conflict with universal values like health and wellbeing, universal values should take precedence.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Surface Cultural Values May Conflict with Deeper Universal Values
content: Cultural injunctions (like Navajo prohibition on negative talk) may embody empirically false beliefs about how to actualize deeper, universal values shared across cultures.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Medical Obligations Transcend Cultural Variations
content: A physician's obligation to maximize patient health and minimize suffering is universal and not culturally relative, even if cultures impose conflicting obligations.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Universal Values Exist Despite Cultural Differences
content: While cultures differ in some values, certain values (like protecting life and health) are truly universal, though not universally complied with.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Withholding Health-Critical Information Is Always Wrong
content: A medical doctor in any culture who withholds health-critical information from patients is failing in professional duties.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Mill Affords Broader Liberty Than Hobbes
content: Mill's political philosophy affords citizens a maximally expansive set of liberties based on the harm principle, while Hobbes restricts liberty severely to prevent anarchy.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Hobbes' Pessimistic View of Human Nature Justified by Historical Context
content: Hobbes' dim view of human nature and need for strong authority was influenced by witnessing the English Civil War and its anarchic violence.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Economic Freedom Requires Political Freedom
content: Mill understood that political freedom (speech, assembly, religion) is necessary for economic prosperity, not just freedom to transact.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Minimal Government Compatible with Social Order
content: Contra Hobbes, minimal government intervention (beyond preventing harm) does not lead to anarchy but rather to prosperity and flourishing.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Adam Smith's Insights Support Mill's Liberty Principle
content: Adam Smith's demonstration that free economic exchange creates prosperity supports Mill's broader argument for maximal liberty.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Excessive Legal Restriction Harms Economy and Society
content: Laws that do more than prevent harm tend to create a sluggish economy, bloated government, and depressed populace.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Hobbesian Stability Concerns Overstated
content: Hobbes' fear that freedoms of speech, assembly, and religion lead to civil war and anarchy are overstated; such freedoms are compatible with stability.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Clear and Present Danger Standard for Liberty Restrictions
content: The law should only restrict liberty to prevent "clear and present dangers," not mere anticipations or possibilities (Mill's view).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Truth Is Correspondence
content: Truth is a property of representations (beliefs, statements) that consists in those representations corresponding to or accurately depicting reality.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Truth Requires Representations
content: Truth is not a property of the world itself but a relation between representations and the world. Without representations, there would be no truth (though there would be states of affairs).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Truth Is Objective in Important Sense
content: While truth requires representations (subject-dependent), once representations exist, whether they are true is determined by the world, not by us (objective in relevant sense).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Inference to Best Explanation as Epistemic Method
content: We determine whether beliefs are true by assessing whether they minimize anomalies and coincidences relative to alternatives. Beliefs that best explain available data are most likely true.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: We Cannot Compare Beliefs Directly with Reality
content: We cannot directly compare beliefs with the realities they represent; we only know reality through our beliefs, so justification involves coherence and explanatory power.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Anti-Skeptical Argument from Coherence
content: We can know we're not dreaming/hallucinating because the skeptical hypothesis (mind creating all experiences ex nihilo) posits more miracles/unexplained facts than realism does.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Mental Coherence Indicates External Reality
content: The fact that our mental states are internally coherent and practically useful indicates they represent external realities whose mutual relations the relations of our experiences shadow.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Global Skepticism Posits Too Many Miracles
content: If all experiences arise ex nihilo in the mind without external support, this would be a vast collection of unexplained miracles. Hypotheses that minimize miracles are to be preferred.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Modern Epistemology Errs in Starting with Doubt
content: Modern epistemology (post-Descartes) mistakenly starts with radical doubt (Evil Demon) rather than with belief (Angel of Truth), making it artificially difficult to account for knowledge.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Better to Explain Error in Terms of Knowledge
content: Epistemology should start with paradigm cases of knowledge and explain error as deviation, rather than starting with skeptical doubt and trying to explain knowledge.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Schopenhauer's Fractal Metaphysics A Priori More Reasonable
content: Schopenhauer's view that reality has a fractal structure (micro replicates macro, with will and idea throughout) is more reasonable than materialism which makes mind an inexplicable anomaly.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Materialism Either Absurd or Implausible
content: Materialism either absurdly denies mind exists or implausibly claims mind is identical with physical processes to which it bears no apparent resemblance.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: World as Will and Idea Throughout
content: Schopenhauer's conception that the world is fundamentally will and idea at all levels (not just in humans) avoids the problem of mind as inexplicable cleavage in a purely physical world.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Religious Belief Requires Evidence
content: W.K. Clifford is right that religious belief, like other beliefs, requires adequate evidential support. William James' "will to believe" defense is inadequate.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Religious Believers vs. Skeptics Disagree on Standards of Evidence
content: The debate between religious believers (like O'Reilly) and skeptics (like Dawkins) often centers on what counts as adequate evidence for God's existence.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Arguments from Design and Fine-Tuning Have Force
content: The argument that the universe's apparent design and fine-tuning for life provides some evidence for God's existence is not obviously fallacious.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Problem of Evil Seriously Challenges Theism
content: The existence and extent of suffering in the world poses a serious philosophical problem for belief in an omnipotent, omniscient, omnibenevolent God.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Jaynes' Bicameral Mind Hypothesis Is Speculative But Interesting
content: Julian Jaynes' hypothesis that ancient peoples experienced thoughts as auditory hallucinations (voices of gods) is speculative but offers interesting explanatory power for religious phenomena.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Ancient Religious Experience Was More Direct Than Modern
content: For ancient peoples, religious experiences may have been more direct and experiential (through hallucinations) rather than requiring faith in implausible doctrines.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Modern Religiosity Lacks Psychological Force of Ancient Religion
content: Modern religious belief, not being experientially grounded like ancient "bicameral" religion, lacks the psychological reality and force it had for ancients.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Blindsight Analogy Illuminates Pre-Reflective Consciousness
content: The phenomenon of blindsight (seeing without knowing one sees) helps explain how ancient peoples could be conscious without being self-conscious or reflective.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Religious Figures Now Have "Second-Class Existence"
content: For modern people, God exists as a background figure called upon in need, lacking the primary reality He had for ancients who directly experienced divine presence.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Modern Science Risks Faustian Separation from Nature
content: Modern science's attempt to rise above and dominate nature (symbolized by Faust) risks losing connection with our natural grounding.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Neuroscience Can Potentially Increase Happiness
content: David Pearce's argument that neuroscience and genetic engineering could dramatically increase human happiness has merit, despite measurement difficulties.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Subjective Happiness Not Quantifiable But Neural Correlates Are
content: While happiness as subjective experience may not be quantifiable, its neural underpinnings (neuron firing patterns, neurotransmitter levels) are quantifiable and manipulable.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Psychopathy as Incapacity for Non-Pragmatic Agency
content: Psychopaths use others but do not have relationships with them except of a purely pragmatic kind. To the extent a person is a psychopath, he cannot have meaningful relations with others. Psychopathic agency is purely instrumental, treating others as tools rather than as ends in themselves or as genuine relational partners.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Intentions as System-Level Judgments
content: Intentions = judgments about how to consolidate psychological architecture. NOT desires.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Values Distinct from Desires
content: Values = beliefs about what consolidates psychological architecture. Values ≠ desires (though can interact).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Free Acts as Value-Driven
content: Free acts driven by values, NOT by second-order desires (contra Frankfurt). Second-order desires can be warped.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Rational vs. Intelligent Distinction
content: Rational = embodies due regard for interests. Intelligent = computational power. Irrational acts can be highly intelligent.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Frankfurt's Analysis Insufficient
content: Frankfurt right about higher-order states but wrong that second-order desires sufficient. Rationalization problem.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Compatibilism About Free Will
content: Free will is compatible with determinism. One acts freely when actions result from one's own desires and deliberations.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Action requires unconscious intention, not conscious decision
content: Voluntary action requires an unconscious intention (which may or may not reach consciousness) rather than a conscious decision. The readiness potential represents this unconscious intention forming. Conscious awareness (W) is epiphenomenal regarding the particular action, though it may affect future actions through approval/veto.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Action requires self-change
content: To act is to change oneself. A being that cannot change itself cannot act.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Power presupposes freedom
content: There is a distinction between freedom and power. Power is the ability to convert freedom into desired results. Power presupposes the existence of freedom and must be distinguished from it. A rock has power (effects) but not freedom or the ability to do things in the relevant sense.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Intentions vs desires in action explanation
content: There is a crucial distinction between desires and intentions in explaining action. Intentions are grounded in one's personality; desires need not be. There are free-floating desires that are 'in one, but not of one.' Counterfeit intentions exist where conscious intention differs from unconscious intention.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Compulsive actions achieve opposite of conscious intention
content: The end-result of a compulsively performed action is the opposite of the consciously intended result and coincides with the unconsciously intended result. Compulsive acts of kindness toward mother don't affect her like real kindness but like acts of hostility. Taking mother to endless doctors demoralizes her and weakens her immune system.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Authentic action requires alignment of values and desires
content: Authentic actions must embody both values and desires in alignment. Actions driven by desire without values are instinctual reactions (real but not actions). Actions driven by values without desire are sublimations (actions but not real). Compulsive acts split into two half-actions - one all instinct, one all values - and thus aren't really anything.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Compulsive behavior as leaking not acting
content: In compulsive acts, the actor isn't truly acting - rather, sadism or hatred is 'leaking out' of them. Although compulsive acts discharge negative emotions, it isn't the person doing the discharging. The beneficent side is intentional but lacks emotional support, making it behavior one 'undergoes' rather than 'engages in.'
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Deracinated values possess the agent
content: When values are deracinated (lacking instinctual basis), it is less appropriate to describe them as values that the agent has than as values that have the agent. The agent is possessed by external value structures rather than authentically holding values integrated with their desires.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: True agency requires ideals not just passion
content: True agency is about fulfillment of ideals (not necessarily ethical, but ideals of some kind), not mere desire satisfaction. Where there is desire without values, there is passion (in both contemporary and etymological senses) but not action. An instinctual reaction driven purely by desire is not authentic action.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI Systems as Philosophical Evidence
content: Operation of AI systems provides empirical evidence that can arbitrate between competing philosophical theories. How AI actually works reveals truths about reasoning, knowledge, language, mind.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Classical vs. AI Computing Architecture Alignment
content: Classical logic's properties (explicit rules, step-by-step deduction, binary truth values, context-independence, compositional semantics) match classical computing architecture. System L's properties (flexible search, pattern-based reasoning, degrees of plausibility, context-sensitivity, holistic processing) align with AI systems.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI Vindicates Non-Revisionist Epistemology
content: AI operation provides empirical support for non-revisionist epistemology that accepts knowledge about unobservables/future/counterfactuals, recognizes necessary integration of empirical and rational components, understands theoretical knowledge as based on causal mechanisms and continuity, rejects pure empiricism while maintaining importance of empirical evidence.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI Provides Empirical Test for Logical Theories
content: Artificial intelligence systems, particularly large language models, provide empirical evidence about how reasoning actually works, revealing that System L's approach better captures both human and artificial reasoning than classical logic.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Financial Stability Requires Counter-Cyclical Policy
content: Markets left to themselves exhibit boom-bust cycles. Preventing severe busts requires counter-cyclical intervention: tightening during booms, loosening during busts. The Fed's pro-cyclical tightening after 1929 crash turned it into Depression.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Credit as Essential Economic Function
content: Economies depend on credit as much as on wealth. When credit dries up, economic activity contracts even if wealth remains. Banking crises are particularly dangerous because they destroy credit availability.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Exchange Value is Perception-Based, Use Value is Reality-Based
content: Exchange value is fundamentally perception-based rather than reality-based, while use value is reality-based. For this reason, there is no limit to how much exchange value and use value can diverge from one another.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Wealth Divergence Between Exchange and Use Value Exacerbates Inequality
content: The divergence between exchange value and use value tends to inflate the value of wealthy people's assets and deflate the value of poor people's assets, thereby exacerbating pre-existing inequalities.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: 2008 Crisis Exemplifies Dual Divergence of Exchange from Use Value
content: The 2008 financial crisis was caused by two distinct divergences between exchange value and use value: first, worthless housing was made to seem valuable; second, worthless housing-backed securities created additional false perception-based capital.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Anti-Drug Laws Create Zero-Sum Bureaucracies That Are Net Economic Parasites
content: The state apparatus relating to drug prohibition - educators, probation officers, prison personnel - are zero-sum bureaucracies: useless parasites contributing nothing while being paid at taxpayer expense, actually harming those they supposedly help.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Drug Prohibition is Economic Argument for Universal Drug Legalization
content: For strictly economic reasons (not civil liberty reasons), it is necessary to make all drugs legal unconditionally. 90% of inmates are drug offenders; imprisoning them is expensive and prevents economic contribution; drug offenders are non-violent and don't abridge others' freedoms.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge-Capital More Important Than Property-Capital in Market Economies
content: In today's market economy, knowledge is more important than property. Person with unlimited knowledge but no property can acquire unlimited property. Person with property but no knowledge can only hold position, not grow it. Knowledge alone enables satisfying market demands.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Market Economies Incentivize Education, Command Economies Do Not
content: In feudal or command economies, property seldom passes between persons - such economies are static. Participants focus on property retention not acquisition, so investing in education doesn't pay since no guarantee of marketing it. In market economies there is such guarantee since one can always trade knowledge for property.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Market Freedom Paradox: Freedom Used Rationally Produces Slavery
content: There is a paradox of market freedom: legal freedoms, when disposed of in most rational manner given available options, produce complete enslavement. Rationality and freedom turn against themselves to enslave their possessor.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Fund Managers Profit by Exploiting Exchange-Use Value Divergences
content: Fund managers make money by dumping over-valued assets and buying under-valued assets. Their income depends entirely on detecting discrepancies between use-value and exchange-value. Their activities may themselves enlarge those discrepancies.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Dodd-Frank's real problem is insufficient scope
content: Criticisms of Dodd-Frank (reduced liquidity, expensive infrastructure, hurts small banks, government overreach) are either false or outweighed by countercriticisms. The real problem with Dodd-Frank is that it doesn't go far enough. It prevents certain predatory behaviors but does nothing to limit bank size, and therefore does nothing to prevent the systemic damage megabanks can cause.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Low interest rates and excessive government debt create policy trap
content: Thirty years of low interest rates (1990-2022) led to both inflation and massive government debt (140% debt-to-GDP). This creates a trap: raising rates to curb inflation makes servicing government debt prohibitively expensive, potentially forcing default; but lowering rates causes inflation to rise to unacceptable levels.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Megabanks cause market concentration and poor service
content: The top 11 financial firms manage $46 trillion in a $125 trillion economy—massive market concentration. Moreover, megabanks provide worse service than smaller banks: fewer branches per capita, worse customer service, more fees. Their advantage is political, not economic: 'too big to fail' means they can take excessive risks knowing they'll be bailed out.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: FIRE economy shifts from production to speculation
content: The growth of the FIRE sector (Finance, Insurance, Real Estate) from 14% to 21% of GDP represents a shift from productive economic activity to rent-seeking, speculation, and wealth transfer. FIRE doesn't create wealth; it moves existing wealth around, extracting fees in the process. This represents a fundamental change in economic structure away from manufacturing and toward financialization.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Rationalist Foundationalism
content: Knowledge rests on bedrock of non-empirical, purely logical truths
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Anti-Empiricism
content: Strict empiricism false; non-empirical knowledge required for all knowledge
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge as Non-Accidentally Justified True Belief
content: Four conditions for knowledge: truth, belief, justification, non-accidental connection
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Philosophy Justifies Empirical Science's Presuppositions
content: Empirical disciplines make assumptions they cannot empirically justify. Only philosophy can provide non-empirical justification. Philosophy is meta-science.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Observation Cannot Self-Corroborate
content: Observation cannot justify that observation is reliable. Witnesses cannot self-corroborate. Pure empiricism is circular.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Aboriginal Procedural Knowledge
content: Humans have in-built procedural knowledge of dependence-relations
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Continuity-Based External World Knowledge
content: We know external world by interpolating continuities between experiential data
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Two Ways Sense-Perception Adds to Knowledge
content: Perception contributes via (1) direct content transmission and (2) triggering ratiocinative processes beyond perceptual content
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Principles Cannot Be Sense-Perceived
content: Can perceive specific objects but cannot perceive principles or general truths. Principles grasped through reason.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Non-Empirical Knowledge Exists
content: Some truths are known without empirical justification: mathematical, logical, some metaphysical
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: All Non-Empirical Knowledge is Analytic
content: All non-empirical knowledge concerns conceptual structures. Explicitly rejects Kant's synthetic a priori.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: A Priori Knowledge as Constitutive of Reasoning Ability
content: A priori knowledge = knowledge constitutive of ability to reason. Not acquired through experience but enables learning from experience.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: A Priori Knowledge Necessary for Any Learning
content: Cannot learn from experience without a priori knowledge. Cannot deduce principles of deduction from experience (circular). Must have deductive knowledge ab initio.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: A Priori Knowledge as Subpersonal
content: A priori knowledge not ordinary propositional knowledge but constitutive of subject itself. Principles are ability to think, not objects of thought.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Refutation of Humean Skepticism
content: Induction justified; Hume's argument commits gambler's fallacy
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Gettier Problem: Justification Must Be Non-Accidental
content: Justified true belief is not sufficient for knowledge. The connection between justification and truth must be non-accidental.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Three Sources of Justification
content: There are ultimately only three sources of justification: (a) perceptual evidence, (b) introspective evidence, (c) rational inference.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Testimony Requires Independent Verification
content: For testimony-based belief to constitute knowledge, one must have independent evidence of the source's reliability.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Cartesian Skepticism Refuted
content: Global skepticism is self-refuting. The skeptical hypothesis cannot coherently be entertained.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Inductive Inference Cannot Be Justified A Posteriori
content: The principle of induction cannot be justified empirically without circularity.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Rationalist Solution to Induction
content: The principle of induction must be known a priori if it is to be justified at all.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Universals Cannot Be Sense-Perceived
content: Universals cannot be sense-perceived because they are non-spatiotemporal and perception requires causal interaction.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Thought Requires Universals
content: All thought, language, and explanation require universals. The idea of non-universal-involving thought is incoherent.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Empiricism Refuted by Need for Universals
content: Strict empiricism is false. Since universals are required for all thought and cannot be sense-perceived, not all knowledge is empirical.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Berkeley's 'To Be Is To Be Perceived' Refuted
content: Berkeley's idealism is false. Multiple arguments refute 'esse est percipi'.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Phenomenalism Refuted
content: Phenomenalism (reducing physical objects to perceptions) is false. Carnap's project failed.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Poverty of Stimulus Argument for A Priori Knowledge (Chomsky)
content: Humans acquire linguistic competence from minimal data while non-linguistic entities cannot, proving humans possess innate, pre-experiential cognitive structure (a priori knowledge).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Innate Cognitive Structure Required for Language Learning
content: Language acquisition requires pre-existing innate cognitive structure. This structure is cognitive, not merely physiological.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Language Learning as 'Triggering' Pre-Existing Structure
content: Experience does not create linguistic knowledge de novo but 'triggers' or 'turns on' pre-existing cognitive structures. Learning is activation, not construction.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: A Priori Knowledge as Cognitive Framework (Not Framework Content)
content: A priori knowledge is not knowledge you have (content within framework) but knowledge you are (the framework itself). It is not the object of awareness but the subject that makes awareness possible.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Framework-Knowledge vs Content-Knowledge Distinction
content: Fundamental distinction between (1) structure-internal knowledge (learned, content) and (2) structure-constitutive knowledge (a priori, framework). All learned knowledge presupposes the framework.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Deep Unconsciousness of Cognitive Framework
content: Framework-constitutive structures are 'deeply unconscious' (Chomsky's term) - unlike Freudian unconscious. Cannot become conscious because consciousness presupposes them.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Causation as Continuity Not Regularity
content: For x to cause y is for y to be a continuation of x, not for x-like events to always precede y-like events. Knowledge of the future is based on continuities, not regularities.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge Without Known Justification
content: A belief must be justified to constitute knowledge, but it is not necessary that one know that justification. Knowledge starts with beliefs that are not themselves knowledge but are justified.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge-Seeking as Description Satisfaction
content: Seeking knowledge involves knowing of a description that it is uniquely instantiated but not knowing what that instance is. Finding knowledge involves learning of some object that it satisfies that description.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Learning Presupposes Constitutive Knowledge
content: The ability to learn presupposes knowledge of a kind, but such knowledge is constitutive of one's mind and therefore isn't acquired. All acquired knowledge is learned, but not all knowledge is acquired.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Experiential Learning Hierarchy
content: Learning proceeds through stages of increasing retention and depth: 'I forget what I hear. I remember what I see. I learn what I do.' Active doing produces the deepest learning.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Wisdom from Bitter Experience
content: All wisdom is based on experience, specifically bitter experience. Wisdom involves turning darkness into light - extracting positive lessons from negative experiences.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Induction as Explanatory Not Enumerative
content: Induction is inherently explanatory rather than purely enumerative. Successful inductive inference requires integrating statistical data with implicit theoretical frameworks concerning causation, continuity, and natural kinds. Pure enumerative induction is fundamentally inadequate.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Discovery Follows Logical Principles
content: Scientific discovery follows identifiable logical principles that are truth-tracking rather than merely psychological. Discovery and justification are not categorically distinct but interrelated aspects of theoretical reasoning.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Reverse Brain Engineering as Philosophy of Science Method
content: By building AI systems that successfully replicate scientific reasoning, we can reverse-engineer cognitive principles underlying scientific discovery, providing empirically-grounded philosophy of science.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI Falsifies External World Skepticism
content: AI systems' consistent success at tasks requiring external world knowledge (medical diagnosis, object tracking) demonstrates treating perceptions as causally connected to external reality leads to reliable knowledge. If external world skepticism were correct, such success would be miraculous.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge of Unobservables is Routine
content: Knowledge of unobservables is not only possible but routine when proper theoretical frameworks are in place. AI systems successfully infer unobservable entities from observable patterns.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Future Knowledge Through Causal Understanding
content: Knowledge of future is possible through understanding causal mechanisms and continuities. AI weather prediction demonstrates this through increasing accuracy.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Counterfactual Knowledge is Knowledge of Rule Systems
content: Counterfactual knowledge is genuine knowledge of existing rule systems and their implications. AI systems like AlphaGo demonstrate this through successful counterfactual reasoning.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: No Knowledge is Purely Observational
content: All knowledge requires integration of empirical and conceptual/theoretical components. Pure observation without conceptual frameworks is insufficient for understanding.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Theoretical Understanding Requires Causation and Continuity
content: Successful theoretical knowledge is based on understanding causal mechanisms and continuity. Statistical and theoretical components must be integrated—pure correlation is insufficient.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Gettier Problem Solution: Scalable Justification
content: Knowledge requires more than justified true belief—it requires justification that serves as proper conduit between reality and belief. Gettier cases involve justification that isn't scalable: it may work in one case but fails systematically when applied broadly.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Coherentist Knowledge Architecture in AI
content: Neural architecture of AI systems supports coherentist rather than foundationalist theory of knowledge. Both human and artificial knowledge are best understood as interconnected webs rather than hierarchical structures built on foundations.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI Falsifies Enumerative Induction Model
content: AI systems demonstrate that successful induction does not proceed by enumerating instances and generalizing. Instead, AI uses pattern recognition, analogy, and constraint satisfaction that cannot be reduced to simple enumeration of cases.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Pattern Recognition as Alternative to Enumeration
content: Successful inductive reasoning operates through pattern recognition mechanisms that identify structural similarities rather than counting instances. AI systems reveal this by succeeding at induction without explicit enumeration.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI Resolves Rationalism vs Empiricism Debate
content: AI systems demonstrate that knowledge acquisition requires both innate structure (rationalist element) and learning from data (empiricist element). Neither pure rationalism nor pure empiricism can account for AI's success. The debate is resolved by recognizing both are necessary.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Innate Architecture is Necessary for Learning
content: AI systems require substantial innate architectural constraints to learn successfully from data. This vindicates the rationalist insight that some knowledge structure must precede experience, while acknowledging the empiricist insight that specific content comes from experience.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge Acquisition is Neither Pure Discovery nor Pure Construction
