content: AI reveals that knowledge acquisition is neither pure discovery of pre-existing facts (naive realism) nor pure construction from experience (radical constructivism). It involves interaction between innate processing architecture and environmental structure.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI Solves the Gettier Problem
content: AI learning systems demonstrate a solution to the Gettier problem by showing that genuine knowledge requires not just justified true belief but also that the justification tracks truth through a reliable causal-computational process. AI systems that learn reliably exemplify this tracking relationship.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Reliable Process Theory of Knowledge via AI
content: AI systems reveal that knowledge requires beliefs formed through reliable processes that systematically track truth. This vindicates reliabilist theories of knowledge over traditional JTB (justified true belief) accounts.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge Systems Minimize Anomalies
content: Both human knowledge and AI systems operate by minimizing anomalies - discrepancies between expectations and observations. This convergence reveals anomaly minimization as a fundamental principle of rational cognition.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI Learning Mirrors Scientific Theory Revision
content: The process by which AI systems update their models to accommodate new data mirrors the process of scientific theory revision in response to anomalies. This suggests a common underlying logic of belief revision.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Continuous Properties Are Cognitively Necessary
content: AI reveals that continuous (graded) properties are necessary for cognitive systems to handle uncertainty and partial information, but this doesn't entail that truth itself is non-binary. Epistemic gradations are compatible with metaphysical bivalence.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI Vindicates Pragmatist Theory of Knowledge
content: AI development vindicates pragmatism's core insight that knowledge acquisition is fundamentally interactive rather than passive. AI systems learn through active engagement with their environment, validating pragmatist emphasis on the practical, interactive nature of inquiry.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI as New Epistemic Faculty
content: Interaction with AI constitutes a genuinely new epistemic faculty - a fourth level of observation beyond passive observation, active interaction, and tool creation. AI enables rational interaction with our own capacity for rational interaction, generating unique knowledge.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge is Inherently Perspectival and Interactive
content: AI reveals that all knowledge, even 'objective' knowledge, begins from perspectival, interaction-based data driven by practical interests. There is no view from nowhere - even AI's knowledge is grounded in its interactions with reality.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Tool-Creating Interaction Generates Irreducible Knowledge
content: Creating tools (including AI) generates knowledge that cannot be obtained from merely using tools or observing passively. Each level of reflexive interaction (tool use, tool creation, AI development) reveals new knowledge irreducible to lower levels.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Two Kinds of Knowledge: Direct and Indirect
content: There are exactly two kinds of knowledge: direct (non-inferential, primitive) knowledge and indirect (inferential) knowledge. All knowledge falls into one of these two categories.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: All Theoretical Knowledge is Inferential
content: All theoretical knowledge is inferential knowledge, though not all inferential knowledge is theoretical knowledge. Theoretical knowledge requires reasoning from observations to explanatory hypotheses.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge is Justified True Belief (But Not Vice Versa)
content: All knowledge is justified true belief, but not all justified true belief is knowledge. Additional conditions beyond justification, truth, and belief are required for knowledge.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Two Kinds of Dependence Relations: Causal and Logical
content: There are exactly two fundamental types of dependence relations: causal dependence relations and logical dependence relations. These are distinct and irreducible to each other.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Logical Dependence Relations Not Known Through Observation
content: Relations of logical dependence are not known through observation. They are known a priori, through conceptual analysis or reasoning, not through empirical investigation.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Causal Relations Known Through Observation
content: Causal relations are known through observation. Unlike logical relations, causal dependencies are empirical matters discoverable through perception and experience.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Analytic Knowledge is Always Knowledge of Dependence Relations
content: Analytic knowledge is always and necessarily knowledge of dependence-relations. To know analytic truths is to know how concepts or propositions depend on each other.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Propositions Are the Objects of Belief
content: Propositions, not objects or states of affairs, are the proper objects of belief. To believe is to take a proposition to be true.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge Distinct From Awareness
content: Knowledge must be sharply distinguished from mere awareness. One can be aware of something without knowing anything about it, and one can know things without being directly aware of them.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The Concept of Evidence: Causal Relatedness
content: One state of affairs e is evidence of another state of affairs e* if and only if e and e* are causally related such that knowledge of e's existence provides reason to believe in e*'s existence.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Information-Transmission as Structure-Preservation
content: Information-transmission is structure-preservation. An information-bearing series is one in which earlier events transmit their structure to later events through causal processes that preserve structural relationships.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Information Distinct From Evidence
content: All information is evidence, but not all evidence is information. Evidence requires only causal relatedness; information requires causal relatedness plus structure-preservation.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Information-Transmission as the Basis of Knowledge
content: Knowledge is based on information-transmission. Our sense-perceptions are isomorphs of the objects they represent, inheriting structure from their causes. Beliefs are knowledge only to the extent they are linked by information-transmissive series to corresponding realities.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge Independent of Statistical Reliability
content: The difference between knowledge and mere belief is not statistical. A belief is knowledge if and only if it is the end-result of an information-transmissive series, regardless of the general reliability of the mechanism that produced it.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Biological Impossibility of Extreme Relativist Beliefs
content: It is biologically impossible to actually believe extreme relativist or deconstructionist positions. No one is drawn to such positions because they believe them; they perpetrate fraud for reasons of convenience, ego, and hate.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Parental Instincts as Embodied Knowledge
content: Knowledge of the importance of healthy early-life attachments for psychological health is embodied in parental instincts. Parents, especially mothers, are naturally inclined to bond with their children, particularly when they are young and vulnerable, indicating innate recognition of attachment's developmental significance.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Sellars' Myth of the Given
content: According to Sellars, what makes a given bit of phenomenal content have particular representational content is the addition of background knowledge and contextualizing information. To think that phenomenal content has intrinsic representational content is to commit 'the myth of the given' - a spurious epistemic foundationalism.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Sensations as Property-Indeterminate Without Background Knowledge
content: Visual sensations (and sensory qualia generally) are property-indeterminate by themselves. In non-standard perceptual conditions (e.g., unusual lighting in the tie shop, or wearing magnifying goggles), the same sensation could correspond to different objective properties. Background knowledge about conditions of perception is required to determine which property the sensation represents.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Two Versions of Anti-Foundationalism
content: Sellars' attack on the myth of the given comes in two strengths. Weak version: it is not typically true that qualia by themselves constitute awareness (knowledge) of anything external - something extra is needed to make a quale epistemic. Strong version: it is not typically true that qualia by themselves constitute representations - something extra is needed to give them representational content. Both versions are correct.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Intentionalism Commits the Myth of the Given
content: Intentionalism is a strong form of foundationalism guilty of the myth of the given in both its forms. Intentionalism holds that qualia by themselves have determinate representational content without needing background knowledge, and that background knowledge cannot affect their representational content. This makes qualia foundational, performing representational and epistemic roles in isolation from epistemic context - precisely the foundationalism Sellars refuted.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Learning Correspondence Rules for Non-Standard Perceptual Conditions
content: When perceptual conditions are non-standard, subjects must learn correspondence rules mapping sensations-under-those-conditions to objective properties. This learning requires checking sensations against how things appear under standard conditions. Once internalized, these rules enable immediate perception of properties even under non-standard conditions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Kant's Synthetic A Priori is Really Hard Analytic
content: Kant's 'synthetic a priori' truths (like 7+5=12 and 'a straight line is the shortest distance between two points') are not actually synthetic but rather 'hard analytic' - they are analytic truths that are difficult to recognize as such, requiring cognitive effort rather than immediate apprehension.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Easy Analytic Versus Hard Analytic Distinction
content: Analytic truths divide into 'easy analytic' and 'hard analytic.' Easy analytic truths (e.g., 'circles are round,' 'triangles have three sides') are such that grasping them suffices for knowing their truth - denying them involves psychological as well as logical incoherence. Hard analytic truths (e.g., 'a circle is a class of points equidistant from a given point in a plane') involve only logical incoherence when denied; a sane person could believe their negation without psychic fragmentation.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: A Priori as Epistemological, Not Logical Property
content: For Kant, a priority is a property of our knowledge of propositions, not of propositions themselves. A proposition is a priori not in virtue of intrinsic logical properties but in virtue of how one comes to know it. Consequently, a proposition could in principle be a priori for one creature and a posteriori for another.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Ex Nihilo Events are Logically Impossible
content: There are no ex nihilo (uncaused) events. The spatio-temporal manifold would comprise ex nihilo events only if it comprised events not co-located with other events - only if it comprised events it didn't comprise. Propositions alleging uncaused events (e.g., 'the newspaper spontaneously combusted') are self-contradictory when properly understood.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Induction Justified by Analog Data, Not Digital Propositions
content: Induction is justified by continuous, analog sensory data rather than by discrete digital propositions. The logical basis for induction is precisely what is lost in digitization involved in embodying knowledge in propositions like 'every swan I've seen is white.' We subtly misrepresent our grounds for inductive belief when we try to propositionalize (digitize) them.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Propositions as Schematic Meta-Data, Not Data
content: Propositions like 'every swan I've ever seen is white' are not the data that motivate or legitimate inductive beliefs - they are meta-data. Describing such propositions as 'data' is like identifying a court's finding of guilty with actuality of guilt. We cannot work backwards from meta-data to data, just as we cannot recover subtle speech inflections from stenographer's transcript.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Digital-Analog Compatibility Distinction
content: We must distinguish digital-compatibility from analog-compatibility - what is permissible given propositions from what is permissible given the analog data those propositions schematically represent. Propositions 'the rock will sprout wings' and 'no stone has ever sprouted wings' are digitally compatible, but their analog correlates involve discontinuities and perforations of space-time manifold making them analog-incompatible.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Goodman's Grue Problem Exposes Hume's Circularity
content: As Nelson Goodman showed, given any explanatorily useful property x, we can construct explanatorily useless property y (like 'grue' or 'plopper') such that x and y are indistinguishable from purely statistical viewpoint. This exposes circularity in Hume's reasoning: properties like 'copper' are not inductively innocent but already embody causal/inductive commitments.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Phenomenal States Require Theoretical Context (Sellars)
content: Following Sellars' Empiricism and the Philosophy of Mind: purely phenomenal states are representationally and epistemically empty except in context of knowledge concerning conditions under which they are experienced. Relevant contextual information can be given only in inductively and theoretically committed terms.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Religious sentiment cannot be understood in strictly medical terms; it cannot be deconstructed
content: Religious sentiment cannot be understood in strictly medical terms; it cannot be deconstructed
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Religious sentiment must be understood on its own terms
content: Religious sentiment must be understood on its own terms
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: All empirical beliefs involve an element of faith - a 'will to believe'
content: All empirical beliefs involve an element of faith - a 'will to believe'
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Empirical beliefs are necessarily underdetermined by the data
content: Empirical beliefs are necessarily underdetermined by the data
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Empirical beliefs, when justified, are justified by their consequences
content: Empirical beliefs, when justified, are justified by their consequences
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Religious beliefs are justified by their consequences and are therefore justified in the same way as other empirical beliefs
content: Religious beliefs are justified by their consequences and are therefore justified in the same way as other empirical beliefs
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: All hypotheses, including quintessentially scientific ones, involve an initial leap of faith; their legitimacy is established by their consequences
content: All hypotheses, including quintessentially scientific ones, involve an initial leap of faith; their legitimacy is established by their consequences
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: A belief is rational if it benefits the person who has it
content: A belief is rational if it benefits the person who has it
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The rationality of belief is justified only by its consequences
content: The rationality of belief is justified only by its consequences
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Religious belief involves a leap of faith, but this leap often proves worth making
content: Religious belief involves a leap of faith, but this leap often proves worth making
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The trench-atheist is not really making a leap of faith because he is surrendering to a part of himself (his conscience), not to an external deity
content: The trench-atheist is not really making a leap of faith because he is surrendering to a part of himself (his conscience), not to an external deity
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The alcoholic is only making a 'leap of faith' relative to what his conscious mind knows, not what his mind as a whole knows; therefore he isn't really making a leap of faith
content: The alcoholic is only making a 'leap of faith' relative to what his conscious mind knows, not what his mind as a whole knows; therefore he isn't really making a leap of faith
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Only principled (not accidental) generalizations can be confirmed
content: Only principled (not accidental) generalizations can be confirmed
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: When 'all x's are y's' is read as principled generalization, it has nomic/causal content and is not equivalent with 'all non-y's are non-x's'
content: When 'all x's are y's' is read as principled generalization, it has nomic/causal content and is not equivalent with 'all non-y's are non-x's'
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: 'All ravens are black' (when principled) says that being a raven grounds or causes blackness
content: 'All ravens are black' (when principled) says that being a raven grounds or causes blackness
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge of the future is based on continuities, not regularities
content: Knowledge of the future is based on continuities, not regularities
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Regularities often tell us where to look for continuities, but knowledge of regularities never constitutes knowledge of continuities
content: Regularities often tell us where to look for continuities, but knowledge of regularities never constitutes knowledge of continuities
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Enumerative induction is either non-existent or illegitimate
content: Enumerative induction is either non-existent or illegitimate
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: When we make legitimate inferences about the future, it is on the basis of knowledge of continuities, not observation of repetitions
content: When we make legitimate inferences about the future, it is on the basis of knowledge of continuities, not observation of repetitions
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: We may have knowledge of continuities without knowledge of repetitions; we can know x caused y even with no other cases of x-like events followed by y-like events
content: We may have knowledge of continuities without knowledge of repetitions; we can know x caused y even with no other cases of x-like events followed by y-like events
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: One often knows x causes y without knowing exactly how y is continuous with x, by knowing secondary continuities that require positing a continuity
content: One often knows x causes y without knowing exactly how y is continuous with x, by knowing secondary continuities that require positing a continuity
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Goodman's 'new riddle of induction' is a non-riddle, since it's continuities not concomitances that ground knowledge
content: Goodman's 'new riddle of induction' is a non-riddle, since it's continuities not concomitances that ground knowledge
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Although a belief must be justified to be knowledge, it isn't necessary that one know that justification
content: Although a belief must be justified to be knowledge, it isn't necessary that one know that justification
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge starts with beliefs that are not knowledge; if such a belief is useful (consistent with data, justified), its owner likely retains it
content: Knowledge starts with beliefs that are not knowledge; if such a belief is useful (consistent with data, justified), its owner likely retains it
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: A belief can be justified without its owner knowing what that justification is; this blocks the epistemic regress
content: A belief can be justified without its owner knowing what that justification is; this blocks the epistemic regress
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Looking for information involves knowing a description is uniquely instantiated but not knowing what instantiates it
content: Looking for information involves knowing a description is uniquely instantiated but not knowing what instantiates it
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Finding information involves learning of some object that it satisfies a description one already knows to be instantiated
content: Finding information involves learning of some object that it satisfies a description one already knows to be instantiated
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The ability to learn presupposes knowledge of a kind, but such knowledge is constitutive of one's mind and therefore isn't acquired
content: The ability to learn presupposes knowledge of a kind, but such knowledge is constitutive of one's mind and therefore isn't acquired
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Introspection cannot settle causal questions
content: Introspection can reveal what mental states we're in but cannot reveal causal relations between mental states and behavior. Causal questions are empirical, requiring observation of patterns across cases, not introspective certainty. Therefore, introspection cannot establish that conscious will causes action.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Role of Intuition in Modal Knowledge
content: Modal intuitions (about what's possible/necessary) play a crucial but problematic role in modal epistemology and cannot be simply dismissed.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Arbitrariness as Theoretical Vice
content: When theoretical claims depend on arbitrary choices (with no principled basis), this is a serious theoretical defect even if the theory is formally consistent.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Modal Knowledge via Structural Analysis
content: We know modal truths by examining the internal structure of propositions—how their constituent concepts are arranged and related—not by surveying alternative worlds.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Conceptual Understanding as Basic
content: Some forms of understanding (like grasping concepts and their relations) are basic and cannot be further analyzed or reduced to other cognitive processes.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Meaning cannot be reduced to observable consequences
content: The pragmatist thesis (i) that 'the meaning of a hypothesis lies in its observable consequences' is false. The relationship between a hypothesis and its observable consequences is always contingent, never analytic, as it depends on what operative conditions and causal mechanisms obtain.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Truth is not identical with utility or power
content: The pragmatist thesis (ii) that 'a true idea is one that allows us to control the world' conflates truth with knowledge. What pragmatism incorrectly represents as a virtue of truth itself should be correctly understood as a virtue of our knowledge of truth. It isn't truth that is empowering: it is knowledge.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Truth is not identical with assimilability
content: The pragmatist thesis (iii) that 'true ideas are those we can assimilate, false ones are those we cannot' is false when taken literally. There are highly assimilable false ideas and highly non-assimilable true ones. Truth is not assimilability; rather, knowledge is assimilated truth.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Externalism threatens self-knowledge
content: If externalism is true—if mental content is individuated by external factors unknown to the subject—then subjects cannot have privileged access to their own thoughts. This conflicts with the apparent fact that we have immediate, authoritative knowledge of what we're thinking.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Counterfactuals as epistemic probability relations
content: Counterfactuals are not statements about states of affairs in alternative worlds, but rather express relations of probabilification holding among statements. They register confirmation relations among propositions - the degree of credibility that certain propositions confer on other propositions. The factualist (possible worlds) analysis makes counterfactuals incoherent.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Counterfactuals are crypto-probability propositions
content: 'If A had been the case, then B would have been the case' means: The proposition K and A gives a high probability to B, where K is the conjunction of propositions we know to be true, minus the proposition that A and B were not the case.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Probability is epistemic not metaphysical
content: Probability is an epistemic, not a metaphysical, notion. Probability is a logical relation between propositions, not a property of states of affairs. When we say 'there is a 5% probability that Socrates had four kidneys,' we are saying something about epistemic possibility given our data, not about metaphysical possibility.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: False propositions probabilify other propositions
content: False propositions probabilify other propositions just like true ones. 'The moon is made of cheese' is false, but it still gives very high probability to 'there is a piece of cheese that weighs more than 100 lbs.' 'Kennedy didn't die in '63' is false but still gives probability to other propositions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Counterfactual truth independent of empirical discoveries
content: The truth of counterfactuals is not contingent on empirical discoveries about the balance of determinism and indeterminism in nature. 'If Jones had struck the window, it would have shattered' doesn't become false if scientists discover unexpected mixtures of determinism. This shows factualist analysis is wrong.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The Frequency Theory of Probability is false
content: The Frequency Theory of Probability (which identifies probabilities with observed frequencies) is false. Probabilities are determined by laws and causal mechanisms, not by statistical patterns. Identical laws yield identical probabilities regardless of statistical divergences, and different causal structures yield different probabilities regardless of statistical similarities.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The Frequency Theory of Probability is false
content: Frequency Theory (FT) - the view that probabilities are identical with statistical frequencies - is false. Refuted by W1/W2 thought experiment and smoking-cancer example.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Truth out of context as damaging as falsehood
content: Truths taken out of context, or made available to people who don't know how to contextualize them, can be as damaging as falsehoods and lead to confusion that enables acceptance of falsehoods.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Plato's extreme rationalism is political, not epistemological
content: Plato's radical epistemological claim that observables are unreal 'shadows' while only pure thought accesses reality is not genuine epistemology but political belief presented as epistemological belief, driven by fear of political change.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Plato's epistemology rationalizes his social position
content: Plato's epistemological views make little sense as epistemology but make perfect sense as attempts to rationalize and preserve his privileged social position against threatening changes.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Descartes' epistemology responds to Church authority crisis
content: Descartes' epistemological project was fundamentally an attempt to cope with social unrest caused by science stripping Catholic Church of credibility. He sought new certainties to replace discredited Church certainties.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Extreme rationalism correlates with anxiety about social change
content: Both Plato and Descartes advocate extreme rationalism (overplaying role of thought, underplaying observation) because both were uneasy about social changes - Plato unambivalently hostile, Descartes ambivalently accepting.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Empiricizing philosophy enables world-engagement
content: Locke and Hume's empiricism represented attempt to make philosophy engage the world. Their political philosophies succeeded precisely to extent they empiricized/anti-philosophized philosophy.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Empiricism collapses into skepticism/autistic withdrawal
content: The empiricist project ultimately defeats itself: arch-empiricism (knowledge only of direct sensory evidence) collapses into pure skepticism (knowledge only of conscious states), representing the most complete autistic withdrawal from reality.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Political Legitimacy Requires Both Effectiveness and Respect for Freedom
content: A legitimate political system must satisfy both consequentialist criteria (it must actually work to improve people's lives) and deontological criteria (it must respect people's freedom and right to choose their own path). Systems that fail on either dimension are illegitimate.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Pathological Concern with Ethics Derives from Crypto-Criminal Orientation
content: Both obsessive-compulsives and philosophers are pathologically concerned with ethics because they are crypto-criminals whose fundamental orientation is anti-social, but who have draconian superegos and thus suppress their criminal side.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Deontological Ethics Precludes Coercive Wealth Redistribution
content: According to deontological ethics (Kant, Ross), wealth cannot legitimately be redistributed through coercion, even if equal distribution would be desirable. The means (coercing people, thwarting autonomy) cannot be justified by the ends (wealth equality).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Kant and Ross Would Not Regard Wealth Equality as Particularly Desirable
content: Even if there were morally innocuous way of achieving/maintaining wealth equality, neither Kant nor Ross would regard it as particularly desirable state of affairs. They would see it as desirable only to extent necessary for people to treat each other with respect - not clear that wealth equality particularly conducive to that end.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Lies Cannot Be Justified by Unjust Ends They Serve
content: If a conception of justice is fundamentally unjust (denying basic freedoms), then lies told to maintain that conception cannot be distinguished into good and bad lies. All lies serving unjust ends are thereby unjust regardless of intentions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Psychopathic Discourse as Career-Based Integrity Undermining
content: When people engage in hand-waving about deconstructionism, narratives, and critiques, they are revealed as individuals who themselves have no integrity and whose careers constitute attempts to undermine the very notion of integrity. One should promptly disengage from such people.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Psychopathy as Categorical Moral Incapacity
content: Psychopaths lack conscience and are fundamentally incapable of genuine moral engagement. Their callous disregard for others, manipulativeness, and deceitfulness constitute not mere moral failings but categorical incapacity for the moral domain. They cannot form the kinds of attachments and relationships that ground normal moral agency.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Ability-Character Complementarity
content: Human abilities differ little by nature; it is habits and character (diligence, persistence) that separate people. Genius is made through dilligence, not born.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Process Over Outcomes in Evaluation
content: What matters is success relative to failure, not the absence of failure. 'Our greatest glory lies not in never falling but in getting up every time we do.' Successful people stumble many times; their successes, not their failures, define them.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Pace Irrelevance in Progress
content: The rate of progress doesn't matter; what matters is continuous forward motion. 'It does not matter how slowly you go, just as long as you do not stop.'
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Internal vs. External Worth
content: One should not worry that nobody knows who you are; worry that you are not worth knowing. The problem is not lack of recognition but lack of actual merit.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Universal Teacherhood Principle
content: Everyone can be a teacher: from superiors one learns what to do; from inferiors one learns what not to do. 'If I am with two men, one my inferior, the other my superior, each is my teacher.'
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Commitment Completeness Principle
content: Whatever you do, do it with your whole heart. Full commitment to chosen path is more important than which path is chosen.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Anger's Misguiding Influence
content: Under anger's influence, conduct is misguided. One should take a time-out and revisit situations from a calmer vantage. Before acting in anger, think of the consequences.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Conscious will as awareness of unconscious intention
content: The conscious event W that a subject experiences as their decision to act is not the operative intention itself, but rather an awareness of an intention that has already been formed unconsciously. The readiness potential (RP) precedes W by approximately 350ms.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: W is not epiphenomenal despite lacking causal role
content: Although W (conscious awareness of intention) is epiphenomenal with respect to the particular finger-movement in Libet's experiment, it is not epiphenomenal tout court. W has causal effects on subsequent intentions and behaviors.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Libet challenges compatibilism more than determinism
content: The Libet experiment is more threatening to compatibilism than to traditional debates about determinism. The problem is not that choices are predetermined, but that what we experience as conscious decisions are 'on the sidelines'—not the operative causes at all.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Libet's results more radical than Freud's unconscious
content: Libet's findings are more radical than Freud's theory of the unconscious. Freud showed that some mental activity occurs unconsciously while treating consciousness as having real but limited power. Libet shows that even paradigmatic conscious decisions are not conscious decisions at all.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Consciousness integrates internal and external information
content: One purpose of consciousness is to integrate real-time awareness of external events (sense-perceptions) with real-time awareness of internal processes (introspections). Consciousness pools these two datasets, though decisions are made unconsciously.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Conscious awareness serves approval/veto function
content: W (conscious awareness) does not make decisions but rather approves or vetoes decisions already made unconsciously. Acts experienced as conscious decision-making are actually conscious acts of decision-approval. This approval extends to future similar intentions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The illusion of free choice is functionally adaptive
content: The experience of conscious decision-making as the source of our actions (when it's actually approval of unconscious decisions) is an adaptive illusion that prevents consciousness from being overburdened. The 'illusion of free choice' is a small price to pay for cognitive efficiency.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Critique of 'phenomenological datum' argument for free will
content: The argument that we 'just know' we have free will because it's a phenomenological datum is question-begging and misconceived. The cogito is analytically true (thinking requires a thinker), but free will is a form of causation, and causal relations are always open empirical questions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Critique of 'Libet actions don't engage rationality' objection
content: The objection that Libet's results don't generalize because they involve simple actions that fail to engage rationality is unsupported and likely false. First, there's no experimental data supporting this claim. Second, more deliberation makes it less likely that operative intentions are fully conscious.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Philosophers' rejection of Libet uses inadequate standards
content: Philosophers evaluating Libet's data employ standards of proof so stringent that by the same standards, there would be no reason to believe smoking causes cancer. By refusing to accept and model Libet's replicated findings, philosophers blind themselves to valuable information.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Standing intentions cannot be constituents of consciousness
content: Standing intentions (e.g., intention to write a book over three years) are enduring structures like knowledge that 2+2=4. They cannot be constituents of consciousness because consciousness involves momentary events. One can be conscious of standing intentions, but they are not themselves conscious states.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Libet's findings likely extend to complex deliberative actions
content: If intentions governing real-time actions (where consciousness is most heavily involved) are unconscious, it is doubly unlikely that intentions governing complex, deliberative actions are conscious. Complex intentions develop through protracted, largely unconscious thought-processes.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The 0.2 second delay is not mere tape-delay
content: The 0.2 second delay between intention (RP onset) and conscious awareness (W) is not merely the minimum processing time required for awareness. Consciousness operates extremely quickly—sprinters can be conscious of individual steps and sub-components. The delay likely reflects W's functional role as action-monitor rather than action-instigator.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Determinism defined as universal causation
content: Determinism is the doctrine that nothing is uncaused. If determinism is correct, how the world is now determines exactly how it will be in the future, and how it was in the past determines exactly how it is now.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Indeterminism entails some chaos
content: If indeterminism is true, the universe is chaotic to a non-null degree. A single uncaused event makes indeterminism correct, regardless of how minute that event is or how orderly the rest of the universe.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Indeterminism threatens freedom more than determinism
content: Indeterminism is more of a threat to freedom than determinism. Determinism is not a threat to freedom but is actually necessary for it. Indeterminism is as fatal to freedom as determinism is necessary for it.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: External indeterminism doesn't increase freedom
content: If the external world (outside our bodies) were indeterministic while our minds/bodies remained deterministic, we would not be more free. In a highly indeterministic world where baseballs might turn into hawks, we would have less control and thus less freedom.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Internal indeterminism doesn't increase freedom
content: If our nervous systems were indeterministic, we wouldn't be more free. An indeterministic nervous system means current state fails to determine later states, so decisions don't reliably lead to actions. Knowledge at one time wouldn't reliably influence decisions later.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Mechanisms require determinism
content: Where there are mechanisms, there is determinism. Where there is indeterminism, there are no mechanisms. A mechanism is something that can be relied on to produce an output of a certain kind when given an input of a certain kind. Mechanisms exist only to the extent the universe is deterministic.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Indeterministic minds are incoherent
content: The more indeterministic a mind is, the more incoherent it is - its future states fail to cohere with present states, present with past. An indeterministic mind is no mind at all, but rather a series of mutually isolated minds, each existing only for an instant and therefore not existing at all.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Freedom requires appropriate mental state responsiveness
content: Inner freedom consists in one's current mental state embodying appropriate responsiveness to previous mental states, and future mental states embodying the right sort of responsiveness to present mental states. Freedom is about having a mind whose mental states determine one another in the right way, not about having undetermined mental states.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Freedom as causal integration
content: A person is free if their mind is constitutive of the right sort of causal integration. Freedom requires both determinism (causal integrity) and the correct kind of causal structure, but determinism alone is not sufficient for freedom.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Responsibility requires agent-constitutive causation
content: For an action to be free is for the agent to be responsible for it. For an agent to be responsible is for agent-constitutive forces to be responsible for it, which means for them to cause it. Prior to the agent's existence, we cannot speak of the agent being made to do anything. Once in existence, being made to do something consists in agent-constitutive forces being directed contrary to the agent's objectives; doing something freely consists in those forces aligning with the agent's objectives.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Material Conditions Shape Consciousness
content: Material developments (like writing and economic organization) fundamentally shape modes of consciousness, including temporal awareness and rationality.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Socrates operationally trained oligarchic coup leaders
content: Socrates didn't merely 'lay groundwork' for oligarchic coups - he operationally trained the men who tried to take over Athens (Critias, Alcibiades, Charmides). He was assembling a team, not innocently thinking.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Semantics vs. Presemantics Distinction
content: Literal meaning must be distinguished from information through which one identifies that meaning
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Universal Extensionality
content: ALL contexts extensional at semantic level. Co-referring terms intersubstitutable.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Direct Referentialism for Proper Names
content: Proper names are mere labels referring directly to objects
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Direct Referentialism for Definite Descriptions
content: Descriptions refer directly but communicate Russellian propositions
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Against Indirect Referentialism
content: Frege's sense/reference theory for descriptions is incoherent
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Presemantic Implicature Theory
content: New category beyond Gricean post-semantic implicature
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Definite Descriptions as Referring Expressions
content: Definite descriptions ('the phi') are referring terms, not quantificational. Always encode propositions of form 'a has phi'
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Referential-Attributive Distinction as Pragmatic
content: Not semantic ambiguity. Both uses involve reference. Attributive: reference to entity in understood existence claim. Referential: ostensive.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Presupposition Not Assertion
content: Following Strawson: descriptions presuppose existence. Abortive (not false) when presupposition fails.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Against Contextualism
content: Rejects neo-Russellian move that context restricts quantifier domains. Violates Gricean principles.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Against Conventional Implicature Solution
content: D-sentences don't implicate object-dependent propositions via conventional implicature. Violates implicature principles.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Anaphoric Descriptions as Referential
content: Anaphoric descriptions refer to entities introduced by antecedents. Not bound variables.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Logical Form vs Semantics
content: Logical form (inferential structure) ≠ semantics (literal meaning). Same proposition can have multiple logical forms.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Logical Form vs Grammatical Form (Frege's Insight)
content: Logical form is not identical with grammatical form. What a sentence says is not always what its grammatical structure suggests.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Propositions as Abstract Objects
content: Propositions are abstract, mind-independent objects that exist outside space and time.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Truth as Correspondence
content: A proposition is true iff it corresponds to reality—if the world is as it says the world is.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Meaning is Not Mental
content: Linguistic meaning is not reducible to mental states or psychological facts.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Russell's Theory of Descriptions
content: Definite descriptions are not referring terms. 'The F is G' means 'Something uniquely is F, and any such thing is G.'
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Frege's Sense/Reference Distinction Collapses into Russellianism
content: Frege's theory that definite descriptions have both sense and reference collapses into Russell's theory.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Against Fregean Intensional Contexts
content: Frege's distinction between extensional and intensional contexts is a failed epicycle.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Literal Meaning vs Cognitive Significance
content: Literal meaning (semantic content) must be distinguished from cognitive significance.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Semantic Externalism (Putnam's Insight)
content: Meanings of natural kind terms are partially determined by facts external to the speaker's mind.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Systematicity and Productivity of Language
content: Languages exhibit two fundamental properties: (1) Productivity - expressions can be combined into larger expressions, and (2) Systematicity - parts composing complex expressions can be re-arranged to form other expressions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Semantic Rules Are Ultimately Descriptive
content: Semantic rules describe what speakers mean/understand by expressions. They are not purely conventional stipulations independent of speaker practices. For 'red' to mean red just IS for speakers to mean/understand red by 'red'.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Names as Concept-Laden Labels
content: Names are mere labels (non-descriptive), as Kripke argued, but labels 'pick up' descriptive information through how one learns their reference. Semantics (what expressions literally mean) differs from knowledge of semantics (how meaning is known), and this difference explains apparent descriptive content.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Co-referential Names Can Differ in Meaning
content: 'Superman' and 'Clark Kent' differ in meaning despite co-referring. 'Superman is in the building' says that a certain property-set (superhuman strength, flight ability, etc.) is uniquely instantiated and any such instance is in the building. 'Clark Kent is in the building' says a different property-set (reporter, wears glasses, etc.) is uniquely instantiated.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Semantics-Pragmatics Distinction is Real
content: LLMs' demonstrated capabilities provide empirical support for classical theories of meaning, particularly the distinction between semantics (literal meaning) and pragmatics (communicated meaning), and the reality of compositional literal meaning.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Compositional Understanding Emerges from Statistical Learning
content: Compositional capabilities can emerge through statistical learning rather than requiring classical computational implementation. Both humans and AI develop compositional understanding through different but convergent paths.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Literal Meaning is Real but Emergent
content: Literal meaning is real rather than illusory, but emergent rather than primary. It develops through triangulation from contextual uses rather than being foundational to language.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Grammar and Logic Are Aligned
content: LLMs' ability to make correct inferences without FOL-style logical forms suggests grammatical structure itself guides valid reasoning. Perceived misalignment between grammatical and logical form may be artifact of our chosen formal systems rather than feature of language itself.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Logical Form is Cognitively Inert
content: Traditional logical form is cognitively inert: people reason without it, LLMs function without it, it plays no role in actual inference. Logical form is constructed rather than discovered, follows rather than guides comprehension, and is system-relative rather than unique.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Universal Grammar as Neural Architecture
content: Chomskyan insights about linguistic universals can be reconciled with connectionism by understanding UG as feature of neural architecture rather than set of explicit rules. UG constraints operate through architectural properties of neural networks rather than explicit rule-following.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI Vindicates Semantics-Pragmatics Distinction
content: Large language models demonstrate a clear distinction between semantic content (literal meaning) and pragmatic interpretation (context-dependent meaning). The success of LLMs requires maintaining this distinction, vindicating classical theories of meaning against pragmatist attempts to collapse semantics into pragmatics.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Literal Meaning is Computationally Prior to Pragmatic Interpretation
content: AI systems must compute literal semantic content before applying pragmatic adjustments. This computational priority reveals that semantics is foundational and pragmatics is derivative, supporting classical over post-modern theories of meaning.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Context-Independence of Core Semantics
content: LLMs demonstrate that core semantic content can be represented context-independently and then applied across contexts. This vindicates the classical view that meaning has a stable core that pragmatic factors modulate rather than wholly constitute.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI Vindicates Syntax-Semantics Interface
content: Large language models demonstrate that grammatical structure (syntax) and meaning (semantics) are distinct but systematically related. The success of LLMs requires explicit representation of this interface, vindicating classical grammatical theory against attempts to reduce one to the other.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Syntactic Structure Constrains Semantic Interpretation
content: AI language systems reveal that syntactic structure constrains possible semantic interpretations. This supports the classical view that grammar is not arbitrary convention but reflects systematic constraints on meaning composition.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Compositional Semantics Requires Syntactic Structure
content: The ability of LLMs to understand novel sentences demonstrates that semantic interpretation is compositional - the meaning of complex expressions derives systematically from their parts and syntactic structure. This requires and vindicates traditional compositional semantic theories.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Grammar and Logic are Fundamentally Aligned
content: AI language systems demonstrate that grammatical structure and logical form are fundamentally aligned - grammatical categories and relations correspond to logical types and operations. This alignment is not accidental but reflects deep unity of form in human cognition.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Universal Grammar Can Be Implemented Subsymbolically
content: AI demonstrates that universal grammar principles can be implemented through subsymbolic connectionist architectures rather than requiring explicit symbolic rules. The functional role of UG is preserved even if implementation differs from classical theory.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Universal Grammar Principles Extend to Music
content: AI analysis reveals that the computational principles underlying universal grammar in language also apply to music cognition. Both domains share abstract structural principles about hierarchical organization and rule-governed combination.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Presupposition Versus Assertion in Perceptual Reports
content: When sensations are property-indeterminate (as in the tie shop), one cannot assert 'the tie is maroon' based on sensation alone. One might respond that the sensation presupposes rather than asserts a determinacy. But this conflates epistemology with semantics - the point is that sensation doesn't tell you which property obtains, not that it pragmatically presupposes one.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: 'Some' Presupposes Rather Than Asserts Existence
content: 'Some phi is a psi' is not an existence-claim. It does not assert that there exists at least one phi that is also a psi. Rather, it merely presupposes that there is at least one phi. This concerns literal meaning (semantics), not what is conveyed by implicature.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: 'All' is Incompatible With 'Some'
content: 'All phi's are psi's' is incompatible with 'some phi's are psi's.' The former entails the negation of the latter and thus isn't compatible with it. This concerns literal meaning, not pragmatic implicature.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Numerals Express Exact Quantities
content: For any numeral n, 'n phi's are psi's' is to the effect that exactly n phi's are psi's. 'Five elephants can dance' means exactly five elephants can dance, not 'at least five.' If six elephants can dance, the statement 'five elephants can dance' is literally false, not merely misleading.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Incompatibility of Different Numeral Statements
content: If m≠n, 'm phi's are psi's' is incompatible with 'n phi's are psi's.' 'Ten elephants can dance' is incompatible with 'five elephants can dance.' This is an immediate consequence of numerals expressing exact quantities.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Numerals as Substantives Versus Adjectives
content: In '5 + 5 = 10,' numerals function as substantives (nouns), synonymous with 'the number 5' and 'the number 10.' In '5 things plus 5 other things add up to exactly 10 things,' the same numerals function as adjectives. Despite this syntactic difference, the expressions have extremely similar meanings, which would be impossible if numerals meant 'at least n.'
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Sentence Truth-Conditions Versus Proposition Truth-Conditions
content: The logical properties of propositions aren't always in lockstep with those of the sentences (or sentence-tokens) that express them. For definite descriptions with Strawson-type semantics, the sentence 'that phi is psi' has different truth-conditions from the proposition it expresses in context.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Response Adequacy Test for Existence Claims
content: If asked 'do any felines exist?', responding '(A) Yes. There exists at least one feline; moreover, at least one feline is ferocious' is completely non-defective, but responding '(B) some felines are ferocious' is defective. This shows (B) presupposes rather than asserts existence, distinguishing it from (A).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Anti-Gricean Analysis of Quantifiers and Numerals
content: The correct analysis of 'some,' 'all,' and numerals concerns literal meaning (semantics), not conversational implicature. 'Some' means 'some but not all' at the level of semantics, not just by Gricean implicature. Similarly, 'five' means 'exactly five' semantically, not 'at least five' with an implicature of exactness.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: There are different ways of picking out a number: canonical (using usual numerical notation) vs. non-canonical descriptions
content: There are different ways of picking out a number: canonical (using usual numerical notation) vs. non-canonical descriptions
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Taken in isolation, a given action can be interpreted as compliance with any of a plurality of incompatible rules, but independent evidence disambiguates
content: Taken in isolation, a given action can be interpreted as compliance with any of a plurality of incompatible rules, but independent evidence disambiguates
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Wittgenstein's 'paradox' collapses into the trivial point that erroneous hypotheses may be compatible with artificially restricted data sets
content: Wittgenstein's 'paradox' collapses into the trivial point that erroneous hypotheses may be compatible with artificially restricted data sets
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Quine's 'indeterminacy of translation' thesis only appears true if one considers artificially constricted data-sets
content: Quine's 'indeterminacy of translation' thesis only appears true if one considers artificially constricted data-sets
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Sorites paradoxes are solved by replacing binary characterizations with comparatives plus contextually supplied benchmarks
content: Sorites paradoxes are solved by replacing binary characterizations with comparatives plus contextually supplied benchmarks
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Vague terms like 'heap', 'rich', 'part of cloud' implicitly invoke contextual benchmarks; n+1 items are always 'more' than n items relative to some standard
content: Vague terms like 'heap', 'rich', 'part of cloud' implicitly invoke contextual benchmarks; n+1 items are always 'more' than n items relative to some standard
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: 'Superman is in the building' says that a certain property-set (being superhumanly strong, able to fly, etc.) is uniquely instantiated and in the building
content: 'Superman is in the building' says that a certain property-set (being superhumanly strong, able to fly, etc.) is uniquely instantiated and in the building
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Names are non-descriptive mere labels (Kripke is right about this)
content: Names are non-descriptive mere labels (Kripke is right about this)
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Even mere labels 'pick up' descriptive information; one doesn't learn what a name refers to in a vacuum
content: Even mere labels 'pick up' descriptive information; one doesn't learn what a name refers to in a vacuum
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: There is semantics (what expressions literally mean) and there is knowledge of semantics; how one knows literal meaning may affect what sentences mean to that person
content: There is semantics (what expressions literally mean) and there is knowledge of semantics; how one knows literal meaning may affect what sentences mean to that person
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Two utterances with the same literal meaning may convey very different bodies of information to those who know that literal meaning
content: Two utterances with the same literal meaning may convey very different bodies of information to those who know that literal meaning
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: No entity has both meaning and reference
content: Reference is a property of spatio-temporal entities (expression tokens). Sense is a property of Platonic entities (expression types). No single entity possesses both properties. The Fregean picture of expressions having both sense and reference is confused.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: All meaningful expression-tokens refer
content: On the correct conception of reference, all meaningful expression-tokens refer, including syncategorematic expressions like 'or', 'if', and case-markers. These refer to higher-order functions. The categorematic/syncategorematic distinction collapses given a proper understanding of reference.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Sentence-tokens refer to propositions (or proposition-involving functions)
content: Sentence-tokens refer. Forceless sentence-tokens (those embedded in larger sentences without force) refer to propositions. Forced sentence-tokens (those with assertoric or other force) refer to functions involving propositions, not identical with propositions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Sentence-types have functions for meanings, not propositions
content: Sentence-types do not have propositions for their meanings. All sentence-types uniformly have functions from contexts of utterance to propositions for their meanings. This holds even for seemingly non-indexical sentences like '2+2=4'—the uniformity of the class 'sentence' requires this.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Expression-types do not refer; only tokens refer
content: Expression-types categorically cannot refer to anything. Even the expression-type 'Plato' doesn't refer to Plato; it has a constant function (from contexts to Plato) for its meaning. Only tokens of 'Plato' refer to Plato.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Replacing co-referring terms cannot change meaning
content: If two terms genuinely co-refer (refer to the same thing), then replacing one with the other cannot result in a change of meaning. What it means to say that terms co-refer just is that sentences differing only in those terms have the same meaning. All contexts are extensional at the level of literal meaning.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Sentences do not refer to truth-values
content: Frege's thesis that sentences refer to truth-values is false. Sentence-tokens do refer, but not to truth-values. Forceless sentence-tokens refer to propositions; forced sentence-tokens refer to functions involving propositions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Apparent failures of extensionality explained by literal vs. communicated meaning
content: Apparent counterexamples to extensionality (like belief contexts and modal contexts) result from confusing literal meaning with communicated meaning. 'John believes the inventor of bifocals snored' and 'John believes the first postmaster general snored' differ in what they communicate but coincide in literal meaning.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Frege's sense-reference distinction is confused
content: The Fregean sense-reference distinction involves fundamental confusions. Sense should not be conceived as a mode of presentation possessed by referring expressions. Rather, sense is a property of types (functions from contexts to referents) and reference is a property of tokens.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Analytic Truth Defined by Content Alone
content: Analytic truths hold entirely in virtue of own content. Given only what they say, could not fail to be true.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Tautologies are NOT Analytic Truths
content: Tautologies = definitional truths about word usage (empirical). No analytic truths are tautologies.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: All Mathematical Truths are Analytic
content: Every mathematical truth is analytic. Mathematical knowledge = non-empirical knowledge of conceptual relations.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Not All Analytic Truths are Mathematical
content: Philosophy has its own domain of analytic truths. Example: 'All math truths are analytic' is analytic but philosophical.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Analytic Truth vs. Formal Truth Distinction
content: Analytic truth ≠ formal truth. Formally true = recursively definable. Math truths analytic but not formal.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Incompleteness as Non-Recursive-Definability
content: Incomplete = no recursive definition. Most scientifically important statement-sets incomplete.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Sorites Vagueness Admitted
content: The sorites paradox is genuine and shows that vague predicates lack sharp boundaries. There are borderline cases where no determinate fact makes a predicate apply or not apply.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Logic is Incomplete (More General than Gödel)
content: Class of all logics not itself recursively definable. Logic is incomplete. More general than Gödel's result.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Logic as Recursively Defined Statement-Set
content: A logic = recursively defined statement-set = axiomatic system
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Logicism Defended (Frege's Project)
content: Arithmetic is reducible to logic. Mathematical truths are logical truths.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Classical Logic as Formalization Not Discovery
content: Classical logic is fundamentally inadequate as a tool for reasoning because it requires more intelligence to recognize that an inference instantiates a logical law than to recognize the validity of the inference directly. Logic organizes existing knowledge about entailment but cannot generate new knowledge about entailment relationships.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Performance vs. Competence-Demanding Inferences
content: Two fundamentally different types of inferential challenges exist: (1) Performance-demanding (straining computational/memory resources), (2) Competence-demanding (requiring genuine insight). Classical logic can only assist with the former.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: System L: AI-Based Discovery Logic
content: A radically different logical system exists in AI that actually helps reasoning through: (1) semantic networks representing concepts as relationship nodes, (2) meta-reasoning patterns generating new inferences, (3) defeasible reasoning allowing provisional inferences.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Discovery-Justification Distinction in Logic
content: System L maintains crucial distinction between discovery procedures (can use any methods including inductive/analogical) and verification procedures (must employ deductive methods in deductive domains). Avoids psychologism while enabling reasoning assistance.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI Logic as Ampliative vs. Classical Logic as Transformative
content: AI-logic is inherently ampliative (generating genuinely new knowledge), while classical logic is purely transformative (rearranging existing knowledge). Only AI-logic can serve as genuine discovery tool.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Classical Logic Fails as a Tool for Reasoning
content: Classical logic fundamentally fails as a tool for reasoning because recognizing that an inference instantiates a logical law requires more intelligence than recognizing the validity of the inference directly. Logic organizes existing knowledge about entailment but cannot generate new knowledge.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Performance-Demanding vs Competence-Demanding Inferences Distinction
content: Inferential challenges divide into performance-demanding (requiring computational/memory resources) and competence-demanding (requiring genuine insight). Classical logic can only assist with the former, not the latter - the very kind that most need logical assistance.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Gödel's Incompleteness Refutes Logic as Mathematical Foundation
content: Gödel's demonstration that not even arithmetic is recursively definable makes the reduction of mathematics to logic impossible in principle. Logic cannot both justify and generate mathematical knowledge as was hoped.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: System L: Discovery Logic via AI
content: A new logical system (System L) embodied in certain AI forms represents a decisive break from classical logic. It employs semantic networks, meta-reasoning patterns, and defeasible reasoning to actually help with competence-demanding inferences rather than merely cataloging known-valid inferences.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Semantic Networks Enable Competence-Level Reasoning
content: System L represents concepts as nodes in a vast web of relationships capturing not just formal logical connections but probabilistic associations, causal links, and analogical mappings. This enables insight-level reasoning that formal logic cannot provide.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Meta-Reasoning Patterns Generate New Inferences
content: System L uses higher-order templates for generating new inferences that go beyond simple deductive rules. Example template: 'If capability X requires mechanism Y, and mechanism Y can malfunction in way Z, then X implies the potential for Z-type malfunctions.'
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Defeasible Reasoning Mirrors Actual Human Reasoning
content: Incorporating defeasible reasoning - provisional inferences that can be revised in light of new information - better mirrors actual human reasoning and provides more practical utility than classical logic's requirement for absolute certainty.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Grammatical Structure Guides Logical Inference
content: LLMs successfully perform logical reasoning by following grammatical structure, demonstrating that surface grammar encodes logical relationships. This vindicates the traditional view that grammatical form reveals logical form.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Entailment Defined as Logical Consequence
content: P entails Q if and only if Q is a logical consequence of P. If P entails Q and P is true, then Q must be true and may be legitimately inferred from P.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Confirmation Defined as Probability-Increase
content: P confirms Q if and only if P, supposing it true, increases the likelihood that Q is true. Confirmation does not by itself license inference from P to Q.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Conditions for Legitimate Inductive Inference
content: Q may legitimately be inferred from P if and only if: (a) the supposition that P is true and Q is false has fewer unexplainable consequences than the supposition that P and Q are both true, AND (b) the supposition that P is true has fewer unexplainable consequences than the supposition that P is false.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Four Principles: Entailment vs. Confirmation
content: Four logical principles hold: (i) Entailment is transitive; (ii) Confirmation is not transitive; (iii) Entailment is monotonic; (iv) Confirmation is non-monotonic. These differences show entailment and confirmation are fundamentally different relations.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Entailment Not Maximal Confirmation
content: Entailment is not maximal confirmation. Entailment is a logical notion concerning what is counterlogical; confirmation is an explanatory notion concerning what is counterexplanatory.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Confirmation-Relations Non-Objectual in Nature
content: Confirmation relations, though not themselves causal relations, sometimes hold in virtue of causal relations. But confirmation relates propositions, not objects or events.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The Counterfactual Analysis of Causality (CAC) Is False
content: The Counterfactual Analysis of Causality - the view that 'e caused e*' means 'if e hadn't happened, e* wouldn't have happened' - is both extensionally and intensionally false.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Generalization from Color to All Perceivable Properties
content: The argument about color-indeterminacy of sensations under non-standard lighting conditions generalizes to any perceivable property P. Distance perception provides the key example: when viewing through variable magnification (microscope/telescope goggles), visual sensations are distance- and size-indeterminate until background knowledge establishes the correspondence rule.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Standard Logical Quantifier Semantics Conflicts With Natural Language
content: Most contemporary logicians and philosophers assume or explicitly state that each of the five points (about 'some,' 'all,' and numerals) is false, and much of what they say crumbles unless they're right. But the points are correct, showing standard logical semantics for quantifiers and numerals diverges from natural language meanings.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Validity of Argument Reveals Semantic Content
content: The argument 'Given that Smith has seven cars, he has an odd number of cars' is valid. This reveals that 'seven' means exactly seven, not 'at least seven,' since if 'seven' meant 'at least seven,' the argument would be invalid (as 'at least seven' is compatible with even numbers).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: 'True of itself' when meaningful abbreviates some non-reflexive construction; when it doesn't, 'self' is an undefined pronoun (free variable)
content: 'True of itself' when meaningful abbreviates some non-reflexive construction; when it doesn't, 'self' is an undefined pronoun (free variable)
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: It is propositions (underlying meanings), not words per se, that are true or false
content: It is propositions (underlying meanings), not words per se, that are true or false
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: If h is synonymous with 'the referent of h+1', then h is defined in terms of an expression itself defined in terms of h, and h consequently has no referent
content: If h is synonymous with 'the referent of h+1', then h is defined in terms of an expression itself defined in terms of h, and h consequently has no referent
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: There is no recursive definition of the class of recursive definitions (Kuczynski's Recursion Paradox)
content: There is no recursive definition of the class of recursive definitions (Kuczynski's Recursion Paradox)
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: There is no formal characterization of formal truth (corollary of Recursion Paradox)
content: There is no formal characterization of formal truth (corollary of Recursion Paradox)
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Everything can be automated except for automation itself (Automation Paradox)
content: Everything can be automated except for automation itself (Automation Paradox)
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Trinity doctrine is logically incoherent
content: The orthodox Christian doctrine of the Trinity ('three persons, one God') is logically incoherent. If God, Jesus, and Holy Spirit are genuinely three distinct persons, there are three gods (polytheism). If they're not genuinely distinct, the Trinity collapses into modalism or unitarianism. No coherent interpretation makes them both three and one.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Tractatus vs. Later Wittgenstein on Contradiction
content: Wittgenstein's early view (Tractatus) that all inconsistency reduces to explicit contradiction was questioned in his later work, which recognized irreducible forms of inconsistency.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Set-Theoretic Foundations and Paradoxes
content: Attempts to use set theory as a foundation for semantics and modal metaphysics face fundamental paradoxes related to self-reference and circularity.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Logic as the study of formal truth
content: Logic is the study of formal truth. A formal truth is a statement that holds entirely in virtue of its own structural properties, such as 'it is either raining or it isn't' or 'there are continuous functions that cannot be differentiated at any point.'
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Mathematical logic studies statement-functions
content: Mathematical logic is logic done with mathematical concepts and techniques. The central concept of mathematics is function (a rule assigning objects to objects). Mathematical logic studies statement-functions - functions that assign statements to statements - while other branches study numerical functions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Negation preserves incompatibility
content: The negation of a statement is incompatible with that statement - they cannot simultaneously be true. To properly negate a statement, put 'it is not the case that' in front of it. The negation of 'someone is tall' is 'nobody is tall' (not 'someone is not tall'), since the latter can be true simultaneously with the former.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Truth-functional operators defined by truth tables
content: Conjunction, disjunction, and negation are truth-functional: whether the output sentence is true depends only on whether input sentences are true. 'P and Q' is true iff both P and Q are true. 'P or Q' is false iff both P and Q are false. 'Not-P' is true iff P is false.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Non-truth-functional operators exist
content: 'Because' and epistemic operators like 'Jim knows that' are non-truth-functional. Even if P and Q are both true, 'P because Q' isn't necessarily true. Similarly, given only that P is true, it doesn't follow that 'Jim knows that P' is true.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Recursive functions define logical systems
content: Each logical function (negation, conjunction, disjunction) is defined for its own outputs - you can negate negations, conjoin conjunctions, etc., indefinitely. This means each function is recursive. A system of logic is a recursively defined statement class, and logic is the study of such classes. This is what it means to say logic is the study of formal truth.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The Slingshot argument is unsound
content: The Slingshot argument, which purports to show that sentences refer to truth-values, contains profound errors and proves things that are obviously false (e.g., that your car is identical with Mozart's favorite wig). The argument must be rejected by finding its errors rather than accepting its conclusions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Platonism about Properties
content: Properties exist as non-spatiotemporal entities distinct from instances
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Propositions as Sets of Properties
