content: Propositions are sets of properties; truth is instantiatedness
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Anti-Constructivism
content: Constructivism self-refuting through reductio
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Properties as Non-Spatiotemporal Entities (Platonism)
content: Properties exist as non-spatiotemporal entities. They are not identical with their instances.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Uninstantiated Properties Exist
content: Properties can exist even when nothing has them. The property of being a unicorn exists.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Determinism vs Randomness vs Unpredictability
content: Determinism, randomness, and predictability are distinct concepts that must not be conflated.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Personal Identity Through Time
content: Personal identity consists in psychological continuity, not bodily continuity.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Causality as Counterfactual Dependence
content: Event A causes event B iff: (1) both occur, and (2) had A not occurred, B would not have occurred.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Binary Truth Despite Continuous Representation
content: AI systems demonstrate that truth remains fundamentally binary (true/false) even though cognitive systems represent information continuously. Continuous confidence values or fuzzy representations are epistemic features, not ontological features of truth itself.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Causation as the Essence of Temporal Precedence
content: For one event e to precede another event e* is for there to be a possible causal process beginning with e and ending with e*. Simultaneity is the absence of such a process.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Continuity as the Essence of Causation
content: Effects are continuations of their causes. Causation essentially involves continuity - causal processes preserve structural relationships across temporal intervals without gaps.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Causation a Relation Between Events, Not Objects
content: Causation is fundamentally a relation between events, not between objects. Objects participate in causal relations only derivatively, in virtue of events involving those objects.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Conditions Identical with Event-Patterns
content: Conditions are identical with event-patterns. A condition is not a state but rather a pattern or type of event sequence that can be instantiated multiple times.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: So-Called Changes Typically Identical with Meta-Changes
content: What are ordinarily called changes are typically meta-changes - changes in the rate, direction, or pattern of already-occurring changes rather than absolute transitions from rest to motion or vice versa.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Threshold Effects and Psychological Overdetermination
content: In psychology, causation often involves exceeding thresholds rather than simple sufficient conditions. An effect may require the confluence of multiple reasons, none sufficient alone but jointly sufficient once a threshold is exceeded.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Threshold Effects and the Analog-Digital Distinction
content: Discontinuous changes tend to involve threshold effects; continuous changes do not. To the extent the world changes discontinuously it has digital structure; to the extent continuously, analog structure.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Causes as INUS-Conditions
content: In most contexts, to say 'X caused Y' means 'X was an INUS condition for Y' - an Insufficient but Non-redundant part of an Unnecessary but Sufficient condition for Y's occurrence.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Counterfactuals Hold in Virtue of Dependence-Relations
content: All counterfactuals affirm the existence of instances of necessitation of some kind. Causal counterfactuals hold in virtue of causal dependence-relations; logical counterfactuals hold in virtue of logical dependence-relations.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: David Lewis's Possible Worlds Analysis of Counterfactuals Rejected
content: David Lewis's analysis of counterfactuals in terms of similar possible worlds is false. Events have deep causal roots such that changing one event requires either massive world-differences or changes to deterministic mechanisms.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Program-Causality Distinguished from Token-Causality
content: Program-causality differs from token-causality. Sometimes the appropriate causal explanation cites a condition that guaranteed occurrence of token-causes rather than the token-causes themselves.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Causal Redundancy Defeats Counterfactual Analysis
content: Where there is causal redundancy, causal truths cannot be converted into counterfactual truths. 'X caused Y' can be true even when 'if X hadn't occurred, Y wouldn't have occurred' is false.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Necessary Truths Don't Describe the Empirical World
content: If proposition P is necessarily true, then P doesn't describe the empirical world in any way at all. P's being true in world W₁ doesn't distinguish W₁ from W₂ or any other possible world. A 'description' that fails to distinguish its object from other possible objects is no description at all.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Transcendental Deduction of World-Structure from Coherent Experience
content: There is a hard-analytic connection between 'there exist beings who have cognitive wherewithal to raise metaphysical questions' and propositions about world-structure: any two events are related in space or time; there are causal relations among states of affairs; objects are things in which properties inhere (not mere bundles); human beings are things in which perceptions inhere (not mere bundles).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: To be at rest is to fail to move during a non-null interval; an object at a point during its motion is not at rest
content: To be at rest is to fail to move during a non-null interval; an object at a point during its motion is not at rest
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Any finite number can be represented as sum of infinite series; any case of motion involves traversing infinitely many finite distances in finite time
content: Any finite number can be represented as sum of infinite series; any case of motion involves traversing infinitely many finite distances in finite time
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Space-time regions do not themselves have places; they are constituents, not occupants, of space-time
content: Space-time regions do not themselves have places; they are constituents, not occupants, of space-time
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: For x to cause y is for y to be a continuation of x, not for x-like events to always precede y-like events
content: For x to cause y is for y to be a continuation of x, not for x-like events to always precede y-like events
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Continuity represents preservation; discontinuity represents ex nihilo change
content: Continuity represents preservation; discontinuity represents ex nihilo change
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The legitimacy of inference from cause to effect lies in the irrationality of positing spontaneities
content: The legitimacy of inference from cause to effect lies in the irrationality of positing spontaneities
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Eternal matter vs. creation ex nihilo
content: There are two fundamentally different metaphysical pictures: (1) creation ex nihilo, where God creates being from non-being, making God absolutely primary and matter derivative; (2) eternal matter, where God organizes pre-existing matter, making God and matter coequal ultimates. These lead to radically different theologies.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Pre-Civilizational Perception as Direct and Natural
content: Pre-civilizational humans perceived agency and meaning in natural phenomena (lightning as divine wrath) directly and naturally, not through cultural interpretation or belief.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Modal Realism's Ontological Extravagance
content: Modal realism requires accepting the concrete existence of infinitely many alternative universes, an ontological commitment many philosophers find unacceptably extravagant.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Essentialism and Modal Knowledge
content: The doctrine that objects have essential properties (properties they must have to exist) creates special problems for modal analysis but may be unavoidable.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Space-Time Structure and Modality
content: Questions about the structure of space-time (whether it's absolute or relational, whether space and time are unified) have implications for modal metaphysics.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The universe is counter-entropic through life
content: While the physical universe is entropic (disintegrating according to thermodynamics), biological reality is counter-entropic - organisms grow and assume increasingly sophisticated energy-efficient forms. This counter-entropic tendency is even stronger at the psychological level.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Indeterminism prevents composite objects
content: In an indeterministic universe, composite objects like billiard balls couldn't exist. The trillions of micro-particles would not be kept in place by deterministic laws and would go their own ways, causing the object to disintegrate or never form in the first place. Even atoms require deterministic laws among their parts to exist.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: States of affairs are causal processes
content: It is part of our concept of a state of affairs (excluding completely instantaneous ones) that such things are causal sequences. States of affairs cannot be understood as non-causal. This undermines Humean attempts to define causation in terms of regularities among states of affairs.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Temporal priority defined causally
content: Temporal succession is itself a causal notion. A standard definition: x precedes y iff some possible (or actual) causal sequence connects x to y. Given that forces are deformations of space-time and no two events are totally causally isolated, x precedes y iff there is some causal process starting with x that ends with y.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Truth is discovered, not made
content: The pragmatist thesis (v) that 'truth is made, not discovered' is false. The negation (vN) 'truth is discovered, not made' is correct. Truth is objective—either there is an even number of stars in the galaxy or there isn't, independently of human construction.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge is a subject-object relationship; truth is objective
content: Truth is objective—it concerns facts about the world independent of knowers. But knowledge is a relationship between subject and object, between mind and world, and therefore has a subjective side. Speaking biologically, the intellect exists to help the organism survive and procreate, though in humans it has become partly autonomous.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Cell Biology Analogy Supports Collective-First Methodology
content: Just as individual cells are better understood in terms of their role in multicellular organisms rather than as autonomous individuals pursuing their own survival, individual humans are better understood in terms of their roles in human collectives. Cell-individualism can be explained in terms of cell-collectivism, but not vice versa; similarly for person-individualism and person-collectivism.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Collective Behavior Cannot Be Explained by Individualist Assumptions
content: It is very difficult to explain group behavior - whether mobs or advanced cultures - on the assumption that collectives represent averages of behaviors of autonomous individual deciders. Outside of contexts with immediate physical threats or prospects of crude gratification, people give far too much weight to existing beliefs and mores in far too well-defined ways to be accounted for by individualist hypotheses.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI Construction Tests Cognitive Theories Empirically
content: The requirement that cognitive theories be implementable in functioning AI systems provides an empirical constraint: theories that cannot generate working systems are falsified. This connects abstract theorizing to concrete engineering requirements.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Formalization Requires Generative Not Just Organizational Adequacy
content: AI reveals that adequate formalization requires not just organizing existing knowledge but generating new valid instances. A formalization is adequate only if it can generate the full range of valid cases, not merely classify them post hoc.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Generative Tests Reveal Hidden Inadequacies in Formalizations
content: Testing whether a formalization can generate valid new instances (as AI systems must) reveals inadequacies invisible to purely organizational approaches. Many traditional formalizations fail this stronger generative test.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: No Such Thing as Enumerative Induction
content: There is no such thing as enumerative induction (inferring 'all Fs are Gs' from 'all observed Fs are Gs'). What appears to be enumerative induction always involves implicit appeal to Inference to the Best Explanation (IBE).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Discontinuity-Elimination the Essence of Explanation
content: To explain is to eliminate discontinuities. A correct scientific hypothesis eliminates anomalies by showing how apparently disconnected facts are part of continuous causal processes.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Inductive Knowledge as Knowledge of Continuities
content: Inductive knowledge is knowledge of continuities between continuities. Valid induction extends known continuous causal processes to unobserved cases by identifying higher-order patterns of continuity.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: IBE Justified by Continuity-Completion
content: Inference to the Best Explanation (IBE) is justified because it completes causal continuities. A hypothesis is justified to the extent it fills gaps in causal sequences, eliminating discontinuities in the data.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Measurement Distinct from Enumeration
content: Measurement is fundamentally distinct from enumeration. Length cannot be determined by counting because (1) there are no minimal length units, and (2) length is not strictly additive at large scales.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Relativization to Standards the Essence of Measurement
content: The essence of measurement is comparison with respect to a standard. All measurement, including 'absolute' measurement, is fundamentally relative comparison to stipulated standards.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Three Axioms of Measurement Theory
content: Three axioms are necessary for any viable measurement system: (i) If L1>L2 and L2>L3, then L1>L3 (transitivity). (ii) If L1≠L2, one is greater (trichotomy). (iii) If L1=L2 and L2=L3, then L1=L3 (transitivity of identity). Violation makes measurement meaningless.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Metrical Conventionalism Versus Strict Conventionalism
content: Conventionalism (laws are convention-based) differs from strict conventionalism (laws are convention-determined). Only the former is correct. That laws are expressed relative to conventional standards doesn't make them entirely conventional.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Conventionalism Self-Defeating
content: Conventionalism is self-defeating. If laws hold in virtue of non-conventional relations between conventions and events (as conventionalism requires), then measurement standard choice is constrained by objective facts, undermining conventionalism.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Effective Therapy Requires Purpose-Oriented Reengagement
content: The way to beat OCD is to have a purpose in life and choose growth over mere freedom from anxiety. Cognitive-behavioral therapy has shallow, short-lived effects absent determination to grow and change in ways that make OCD irrelevant.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The #1 Rule of Writing is that one must immediately write down every thought that occurs
content: The #1 Rule of Writing is that one must immediately write down every thought that occurs
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: If one waits to write down a thought, the moment will pass and never be recovered
content: If one waits to write down a thought, the moment will pass and never be recovered
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The idea that originally comes to mind in writing is merely a foil for a constellation of unconscious ideas
content: The idea that originally comes to mind in writing is merely a foil for a constellation of unconscious ideas
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Following the immediate-writing injunction makes one ipso facto an honest writer
content: Following the immediate-writing injunction makes one ipso facto an honest writer
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Complete honesty is the #1 rule of writing (compatible with the immediate-writing rule)
content: Complete honesty is the #1 rule of writing (compatible with the immediate-writing rule)
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: In business, one must do what comes naturally and not go against one's own grain
content: In business, one must do what comes naturally and not go against one's own grain
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: One must work hard, but not work hard fighting one's own nature
content: One must work hard, but not work hard fighting one's own nature
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Mind-cure (hypnosis-based precursor of psychoanalysis) has effects similar to religious conversion
content: Mind-cure (hypnosis-based precursor of psychoanalysis) has effects similar to religious conversion
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Mind-cure is effective because it relaxes the conscious-unconscious boundary, mending internal divisions
content: Mind-cure is effective because it relaxes the conscious-unconscious boundary, mending internal divisions
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Psychoanalysis lowers the consciousness-unconsciousness barrier gradually, so emotional changes happen correspondingly slowly
content: Psychoanalysis lowers the consciousness-unconsciousness barrier gradually, so emotional changes happen correspondingly slowly
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Recovering from alcoholism tends to involve helping other alcoholics recover
content: Recovering from alcoholism tends to involve helping other alcoholics recover
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Wittgenstein's and Quine's paradoxes are motivated by behaviorist psychological theories and, though meant to support such theories, actually presuppose them and show how broken they are
content: Wittgenstein's and Quine's paradoxes are motivated by behaviorist psychological theories and, though meant to support such theories, actually presuppose them and show how broken they are
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Philosophers respond defensively to neuroscience challenges
content: When faced with neuroscientific challenges to cherished philosophical positions (like free will), philosophers tend to respond defensively by dismissing the science, raising standards of proof to impossible levels, or claiming the empirical findings are irrelevant. This represents intellectual defensiveness rather than genuine engagement.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Religious thought prioritizes function over logical consistency
content: Smith's theological method prioritizes the functional religious question (What must God be like for the right divine-human relationship?) over logical consistency and philosophical rigor. This represents a pragmatic rather than rationalistic approach to theology, where practical religious adequacy matters more than abstract coherence.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Levels of Analysis in Studying Phenomena
content: Phenomena like religion admit of both reductive (causal-explanatory) and non-reductive (phenomenological-essential) analysis, both of which may provide genuine truths.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Statement vs. Analysis in Philosophy
content: Many philosophical claims are valuable as true statements while failing as analyses; confusing these roles leads to philosophical errors.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Limits of Conceptual Analysis
content: Attempts to analyze all concepts in terms of more basic ones eventually fail; some concepts must be accepted as primitive and understood through their systematic interrelations.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Theoretical Virtues and Theory Choice
content: When choosing between theories, factors like ontological parsimony, intuitive plausibility, and coherence with science matter alongside formal adequacy.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: All functions reduce to statement-functions
content: While there are many types of functions (numerical, class-to-class, property-to-property), all functions are ultimately statement-functions, even though some appear not to be. This is a deep claim about the foundations of logic and mathematics.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Discipline-relative counterfactual evaluation
content: What a biologist considers counterfactually possible differs from what a physicist considers counterfactually possible because they relativize statements to different data sets within their disciplinary scopes. This may reduce to differences in what propositions are known by practitioners in different fields.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Pragmatism is epistemology posing as metaphysics
content: Each of the pragmatist theses (i)-(v) is a way of replacing an object-oriented conception of knowledge with a subject-oriented or agent-oriented conception. What pragmatism presents as claims about the nature of truth and reality are actually claims about knowledge-acquisition recast as metaphysical doctrines.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Intellectual discoveries emerge from solving practical problems
content: Intellectual discoveries are made by solving practical problems. Ventures are undertaken; roadblocks are hit; workarounds are created; and insights are the 'collateral damage' of these workarounds. Much of physics is fallout from attempts to create better weapons and dams, and much of mathematics is constructed to validate this fallout.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Pure theory must be anchored in practical knowledge
content: Once a discipline is launched, it can concern itself with 'purely theoretical' problems—problems relating to the mutual coherence of discoveries made in solving practical problems. But 'pure theory' tends to be stale and one-dimensional when it ceases to be anchored in practical knowledge. It degenerates into knowledge of empty formalisms when separated from practical applications.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Verification depends on observable consequences, but meaning does not
content: The corrected pragmatist thesis (i+) holds that 'our knowledge of the veracity of a given hypothesis is based on its observable consequences.' This is true and truistic. But it must be distinguished from the false claim (i) that meaning itself consists in observable consequences.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Classical epistemology wrongly treats knowledge-acquisition as passive observation
content: Classical Epistemology (CE) holds that knowledge-acquisition is about taking note of what exists while doing as little as possible to change it, with action being merely a precursor to passive observation. This view is false or at least misleading. Knowledge acquisition fundamentally involves active engagement, not just passive reception.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Multiple Independent Arguments Strategy
content: Major conclusions supported by multiple independent arguments
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Charitable Interpretation Principle
content: Consider strongest versions of opposing views before critique
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Concrete Examples Before Abstract Principles
content: Use concrete examples to motivate and illustrate abstract philosophical positions
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Pragmatics-Constrained Semantics
content: Semantic theories must respect known pragmatic principles. Can't just assert 'implicature explains it' without checking constraints.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Bundle Theory of Personal Identity
content: A person/self is class of all mental contents I-related to given mental content. Two mental contents belong to same person iff there is chain such that each link directly interacts with its neighbor. Direct interaction = no intervening physical events.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Content-Bearing Processes Are Ipso Facto Mental
content: If physical process non-derivatively bears representational/thematic content, it is ipso facto mental (whatever else it is). Content-bearing is sufficient (though not necessary) for mentality.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Anti-Language of Thought
content: We do not think in language (natural or innate)
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Perspectival Theory of Feelings
content: Feelings represent relationship to universe, inherently perspectival
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Systematicity of Mental Representation
content: Cognitive success depends on systematic connection and coherence of mental entity systems
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Mind as Multi-Mapper
content: Mind maps itself onto different structures (musical, graphical, visual, athletic)
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Against Language of Thought Hypothesis
content: We do not think in words. Thought is not conducted in a language-like medium. The Language of Thought hypothesis is false.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Thought Is Prior to Language
content: Thought is logically and developmentally prior to language. One must think to understand language.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Against Burge's Semantic Externalism for Attitudes
content: Burge's extension of semantic externalism to mental content is a blunder. Mental states are individuated by internal features.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Selfhood Requires Values
content: Being a self requires having values and making value-judgments. Selfhood is normative, not merely cognitive.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Cognitive Structure Not Purely Physiological
content: Cognitive structures underlying language and thought are not purely physiological but are cognitive - they encode insight, intelligence, and understanding of logical relations. Pure physiology enables only stereotyped responses.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Sub-Personal Thought Exists
content: Genuine thought (cognitive operations involving understanding of logical relations) occurs at sub-personal level - below conscious awareness. Chomsky's second major contribution to philosophy.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: No Language of Thought Exists
content: There is no Language of Thought (Mentalese). Thinking does not consist in the tokening of internal symbols. Thought cannot reduce to language processing.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Semantic Rule Knowledge Required for Language Understanding
content: To know or understand any language requires knowing its semantic rules. This is trivially true by definition of 'knowing language'.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Tarski's Theorem Blocks Self-Expression of Semantics
content: No language can express its own semantic rules (Tarski's theorem). Therefore semantic understanding requires external meta-language or non-linguistic grasp.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Semantic Regress Refutes Language of Thought
content: Language of Thought hypothesis generates vicious infinite regress. Each language requires meta-language for semantic understanding, ad infinitum.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Language Presupposes Non-Linguistic Thought
content: Any language knowledge requires non-linguistic thought. To avoid infinite regress, semantic rules must ultimately be grasped non-linguistically. Therefore thought cannot reduce to language.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: No Atomic Concepts Exist
content: There are no atomic (minimal, non-interdefinable) concepts. All concepts are constitutively connected to other concepts. To grasp any concept requires ability to grasp other concepts.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Conceptual Atomism Is False
content: Fodor's conceptual atomism (concepts have no constitutive interdependencies) is demonstrably false.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Constitutive Relations Are Not Containment Relations
content: Constitutive connections among concepts are not containment relations or decomposability relations (following Wittgenstein). Azure is constitutively related to navy blue but neither contains the other.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Symbol Containment Theory Leads to Thinking Absurdities
content: If concepts were symbols and constitutive relations were containment relations, thinking about 1,423 would require simultaneously thinking about 1,422, 1,421, etc. This is absurd.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Thought Is Not Computation Over Symbols
content: Mental activity does not consist in computation or processing of internal symbolic code. Cognitive activity is not fundamentally information processing over a language-like medium.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: We Are Not Computers (Consequence)
content: If there is no Language of Thought, and if being a computer requires internal symbolic processing (standard characterization), then we are not computers.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: No Bare Representation: Aspectual Constraint
content: One cannot just represent an object without representing it AS having properties. All representation is aspectual.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Properties Individuated by Relations to Other Properties
content: All properties are individuated, at least in part, by their relations to other properties. Grasping any property requires ability to locate it in 'space' of other properties.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Color Concepts Require Multiple Color Grasp
content: Cannot grasp specific color/shade without ability to grasp other colors. Creature that can represent only one shade cannot represent what's specific about that shade.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Mental Interaction Has Normative Dimension
content: When mental contents interact, result is thematically/semantically appropriate to interacting contents. This appropriateness has no analogue in purely physical interactions. Mental interaction is explicative, not merely causal.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Self-Referential Thoughts Solve Twin Earth
content: When Mary-thoughts are analyzed as involving self-referential thoughts like 'whatever caused this perception is lovely,' thoughts with different external referents can be subjectively identical and agree in content, while self-ascriptive thoughts of this kind cannot possibly be false.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Intelligence is Fundamentally Analog Not Digital
content: Success of neural networks and LLMs challenges computational theory of mind. Intelligence emerges from continuous analog processes that cannot be reduced to pure computation. Most fundamental interactions with world are inherently analog; digital representations are derivative.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Connectionism Over Computational Theory
content: Modern AI based on neural networks aligns much more closely with connectionist theories than with computational theory of mind. Systems process information through patterns of activation across networks of weighted connections, operating fundamentally continuously rather than discretely.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Consciousness Serves Survival Functions
content: Consciousness in biological organisms serves specific functional roles: real-time environmental monitoring, reflexive self-awareness, integration of multiple cognitive processes, immediate damage prevention, action guidance. Current AI lacks these because it doesn't need them—operates in controlled environments without survival pressure.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Consciousness-Like Features Require Unified Real-Time Processing
content: Implementing consciousness-like features in AI would require: unified workspaces for real-time integration of multiple data streams, immediate damage-prevention systems analogous to pain, action-guiding systems analogous to emotions. These differ fundamentally from biological consciousness but serve similar functional roles.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Self as Emergent Hierarchical Organization
content: Self/ego exists but is best understood as emergent property of pre-existing cognitive processes. Various thoughts/perceptions/emotions organized into hierarchies based on survival value. What we call 'self' is this hierarchical organization; 'sense of self' mediates between awareness of external events and internal states.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Cohesion Relations in AI Minds
content: AI systems offer mathematically specifiable cohesion relations: (1) Weight-space proximity (semantic topology), (2) Attention-based binding (dynamic contextual relationships), (3) Loss-function optimization (persistent co-activation patterns). These provide precise models of binding principles uniting mental contents.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Individual Consciousness as Illusion of Agency
content: The appearance of individual choice and individualism per se may be largely illusory. What seems like individual agency may be better understood as individuals occupying specific roles within collectives that are biologically primary.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Individuals as Limiting Cases or Special Roles Within Collectives
content: Bona fide individuals - people who genuinely think for themselves (geniuses) - can be understood as limiting cases of collectives (collectives of one), as rogue actors, or most likely as members of collectives who occupy unusual offices and are therefore wrongly seen as not being part of those collectives.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Individual Drives Exist For Collective Functions
content: The intense drives that individuals have to survive and experience gratification can be seen as necessary for, and therefore explainable in terms of, the collectives to which they belong. Individual psychology is what it needs to be for collective psychology to function.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Functional Replication Reveals Necessary Architecture
content: When AI successfully replicates a cognitive function, the architecture required for that replication reveals necessary (though not necessarily sufficient) conditions for that function. This provides insight into the minimal requirements for cognition.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Music Has Cognitive Architecture Parallel to Language
content: AI analysis reveals that music processing requires cognitive architecture with structural parallels to language: hierarchical organization, syntactic rules, and semantic interpretation. This supports the view that music is a cognitive system with language-like properties.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Musical Competence Requires Innate Structure
content: AI systems that successfully generate or analyze music require substantial innate architectural constraints, suggesting that human musical competence also depends on innate cognitive structure rather than being purely learned.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Connectionism Can Implement Chomskyan Insights
content: Contrary to Chomsky's critique, connectionist AI systems can implement key Chomskyan insights about innate linguistic structure. The debate is not whether innate structure exists but how it is implemented - symbolic rules vs. weighted connections.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI Falsifies Classical Computational Theory of Mind
content: The success of modern AI systems (especially neural networks) falsifies the classical computational theory of mind which requires serial symbol manipulation. Intelligence can be achieved through parallel, subsymbolic processes that don't manipulate discrete symbols according to explicit rules.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Intelligence Does Not Require Symbol Manipulation
content: AI demonstrates that intelligence and rational behavior do not require manipulation of discrete symbols in a language of thought. Subsymbolic pattern recognition and transformation can achieve cognitive competence without symbolic representation.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Analog Computation Can Support Rational Thought
content: Neural network AI systems demonstrate that analog (continuous) computation can support rational thought and problem-solving, contrary to the classical assumption that rationality requires discrete digital computation.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Neural Architecture Constrains Cognitive Possibilities
content: AI neural architectures reveal that cognitive capacities are constrained by underlying computational architecture. Different architectures enable different cognitive possibilities, suggesting mind is fundamentally shaped by its neural implementation.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Multiple Realizability Has Architectural Limits
content: While cognitive functions show some multiple realizability, AI reveals that architectural constraints limit which substrates can implement which functions. This challenges strong multiple realizability theses that treat implementation as irrelevant to function.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Domain-General Principles Underlie Domain-Specific Competencies
content: AI systems demonstrate that apparently domain-specific competencies (language, music) can arise from application of domain-general computational principles to different types of input. This supports a middle ground between pure modularity and pure domain-generality.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Consciousness Has Functional Role Absent in Current AI
content: AI systems demonstrate that many cognitive functions traditionally associated with consciousness (perception, reasoning, learning) can occur without consciousness. This reveals consciousness has a distinct functional role that current AI lacks - likely related to unified subjective experience and certain forms of self-monitoring.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI Success Without Consciousness Reveals Consciousness is Not Required for Intelligence
content: The success of AI at intelligent tasks without consciousness demonstrates that consciousness is not necessary for intelligence per se, but may be necessary for specific types of cognitive integration or self-awareness.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Phenomenal Consciousness vs Functional Consciousness Distinction
content: AI reveals a crucial distinction between phenomenal consciousness (subjective experience) and functional consciousness (information integration, self-monitoring). AI can have functional analogs without phenomenal properties.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Self-Representation Requires Specific Architectural Features
content: AI systems reveal that genuine self-representation requires specific architectural features: recursive self-modeling, distinction between self and environment, and temporal continuity tracking. Not all intelligent systems automatically have these features.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Narrative Self vs Minimal Self in AI Architecture
content: AI demonstrates the distinction between minimal self (basic subject of experience) and narrative self (autobiographical self-concept). These require different architectural implementations and can exist independently.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Philosophical Skepticism Projects Internal Doubts onto External World
content: Philosophers' and obsessive-compulsives' supposed doubts about the external world are displaced, projected doubts about the internal world. Neither has genuine doubts about external reality, but both are doubtful about their internal psyche.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Intellectualism as Reaction to Dark Psychological Depths
content: The intellectualism of both philosophers and obsessive-compulsives is a reaction to and attempt to cloak their darkly retrograde psychological condition. They fancy themselves rational actors when they are actually driven by rage, narcissism, and fear.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: OCD and Philosophy Share Structural Isomorphism
content: There is deep structural isomorphism between philosophical methodology and OCD symptomatology: both involve compulsive doubt, retreat into abstraction, preoccupation with technicalities, projection of internal conflicts, and defense against engagement with reality.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Cartesian Mind-Body Dualism as Defensive Idealization
content: The Lockean/Cartesian insistence on the non-existence of the unconscious and the claim that mind extends only as far as consciousness is a tendentious rationalization—a defensive idealization of the self as purely rational that denies the Nietzschean depths beneath the Cartesian veneer.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Emotions as Reality-Alignment Indicators
content: In histrionic, borderline, and dependent disorders, subjects have a fundamentally non-delusive grasp of reality, but their emotions are not appropriate to the reality thereby made available to them. By contrast, in psychotic disorders, the subject's very grasp of reality is scrambled, with emotions thus out of alignment with reality because reality itself is inaccessible.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Intentionalism Defined
content: Intentionalism is the doctrine that mental states cannot differ in phenomenal content unless they differ in representational content; phenomenology supervenes on representational content. This commits intentionalism to the view that phenomenal content intrinsically has representational content - nothing must be added (no contextualization, background knowledge, or ulterior factors) to secure this association.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Rules of Projection Versus Background Knowledge
content: Rules of projection assign phenomenal contents (qualia) to disturbances of our sensory surfaces, while background knowledge assigns representational contents to those qualia. These have different functions but are part of a cooperative enterprise. Rules of projection do not assign representational contents directly to sensory disturbances.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Consciousness can be stripped of emotional valences while retaining conceptual content
content: Consciousness can be stripped of emotional valences while retaining conceptual content
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Emotional valence and conceptual knowledge are separable components of conscious experience
content: Emotional valence and conceptual knowledge are separable components of conscious experience
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: There is a barrier between the conscious and unconscious minds that can be more or less rigid
content: There is a barrier between the conscious and unconscious minds that can be more or less rigid
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: When the barrier between conscious and unconscious is too rigid, the conscious mind cannot draw on the power in the unconscious mind
content: When the barrier between conscious and unconscious is too rigid, the conscious mind cannot draw on the power in the unconscious mind
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Automatic writing involves 'letting' one's hand write 'all by itself'
content: Automatic writing involves 'letting' one's hand write 'all by itself'
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Hallucinations brought about by religious ecstasies make the unseen presence literally visible
content: Hallucinations brought about by religious ecstasies make the unseen presence literally visible
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Mental states that mediate awareness of unseen presence are similar to those when conscious-unconscious boundary is relaxed (as in hypnosis or drug use)
content: Mental states that mediate awareness of unseen presence are similar to those when conscious-unconscious boundary is relaxed (as in hypnosis or drug use)
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Religious ecstasy involves effacement of self: one's ego disappears, being replaced by pure awareness of divinity
content: Religious ecstasy involves effacement of self: one's ego disappears, being replaced by pure awareness of divinity
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Content externalism has the absurd consequence that a thought's content has no effect on its psychological properties
content: Content externalism has the absurd consequence that a thought's content has no effect on its psychological properties
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Content externalism falsely implies that I cannot know I am thinking about Mary as opposed to Twin-Mary
content: Content externalism falsely implies that I cannot know I am thinking about Mary as opposed to Twin-Mary
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: When thoughts about external world are had via self-referential thoughts ('whatever caused this perception'), thoughts with different external referents can be subjectively identical and coincide in content
content: When thoughts about external world are had via self-referential thoughts ('whatever caused this perception'), thoughts with different external referents can be subjectively identical and coincide in content
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Self-ascriptive thoughts of the form 'I am now thinking that whatever caused this perception is F' cannot possibly be false
content: Self-ascriptive thoughts of the form 'I am now thinking that whatever caused this perception is F' cannot possibly be false
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Mental states divide into occurrent and dispositional
content: Mental states fundamentally divide into occurrent states (momentary, present in consciousness) and dispositional states (enduring capacities or tendencies not continuously present). Beliefs, knowledge, standing intentions are dispositional; conscious thoughts, experiences, decision-awareness are occurrent.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Consciousness as monitoring system rather than control system
content: Rather than consciousness being the locus of decision-making and control (the traditional view), it functions primarily as a monitoring and approval system. Unconscious processes generate intentions; consciousness monitors these and can approve or veto them, extending this approval to future similar intentions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Conceptual Thought Cannot Be Fully Extensionalized
content: The attempt to reduce intensional mental states and contents to extensional structures (sets, functions, physical states) systematically fails.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Control over mind is prerequisite for freedom
content: If a person does not have control over their future mental states, they do not have inner freedom. Someone who cannot govern their own mind is not free, similar to someone with a degenerative neural disorder who cannot govern their body. True freedom requires the ability to make judgments and decisions appropriately responsive to past experiences and controlled by logic and evidence.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Unconscious awareness distinct from conscious awareness
content: There are levels of awareness: conscious awareness and unconscious awareness. One can be aware of something (like a mother's meddlesome behavior) without being consciously aware of it. This unconscious awareness is genuine awareness, though it may not involve seeing things fully for what they are.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Externalism about content is problematic
content: Semantic externalism—the view that mental content is individuated by factors external to the subject—faces serious problems. The work extensively critiques externalism and defends a more internalist conception of cognitive content.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: No Necessary A Posteriori Truths
content: Apparent necessary a posteriori truths are either necessary-and-analytic or contingent-and-a-posteriori
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Epistemic and Metaphysical Necessity Coincide
content: No genuine distinction between epistemic and metaphysical necessity
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Against Possible Worlds Semantics
content: Possible worlds semantics for modality is either false or trivial. It doesn't explain what necessity and possibility are.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Supervenience Creates Circularity for PWSE
content: The phenomenon of supervenience creates an insurmountable circularity problem for attempts to identify worlds with sets of propositions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Non-Circular Supervenience Analysis Makes PWS Unnecessary
content: If supervenience could be analyzed non-circularly without using modal concepts, then PWS would become unnecessary since we'd already have a non-modal analysis of modality.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: PWS Faces Unavoidable Dilemma - Circular or Superfluous
content: PWS faces an inescapable dilemma: either it's viciously circular (using modal concepts to analyze modality) or it's superfluous (we already have a non-modal analysis making worlds unnecessary).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Meta-Language Strategy Fails to Save PWS
content: Relegating modal statements to a 'meta-language' does not eliminate vicious circularity problems for PWS.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Russell's Theory of Types Cannot Save PWS
content: Attempts to avoid circularity by using Russell's Theory of Types (distinguishing 'orders' of propositions) fail in this context.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: PWS Cannot Extensionalize Second-Order Properties
content: PWS's identification of propositions with sets/functions forces it to deny that second-order properties (like necessity) are functions, which collapses the analysis of necessity.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: PWS Cannot Identify Intensional Entities with Extensions
content: Propositions, properties, and other intensional entities cannot be identified with their extensions (sets, functions) without losing essential features like fine-grained individuation.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Inconsistency Without Explicit Contradiction
content: Propositions can be mutually inconsistent without either being the negation of the other, undermining attempts to define consistency non-modally.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Hintikka's Model Sets Presuppose Modality
content: Hintikka's influential analysis of modality using model sets and state descriptions presupposes modal concepts and thus cannot provide a non-circular analysis of modality.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: PWS Valuable as Statement, Not as Analysis
content: Many contentions of PWS are correct and illuminating as statements about modality, but unacceptable as analyses of what modality consists in.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Lewis's Counterpart Theory Faces Circularity
content: David Lewis's counterpart theory, designed to solve problems for modal realism, either involves vicious circularity or makes modal claims depend on arbitrary resemblance relations.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Essentiality of Origins Creates Problem for Counterpart Theory
content: The plausible doctrine that origins are essential to individuals creates circularity for counterpart theory because identifying counterparts requires knowing essential properties, but identifying essential properties requires the counterpart relation.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Counterpart as Primitive Makes Modal Claims Unintuitive
content: If the counterpart relation is taken as primitive (not analyzable in terms of resemblance or essence), then modal claims become detached from our intuitions because they depend on brute facts about trans-world relations.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Properties Have Counterfactual Content
content: Following C.I. Lewis, practically all property attributions to spatiotemporal objects have counterfactual content, which creates deep problems for any attempt to analyze counterfactuals non-circularly.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: 'Innocent' Essential Property Analysis Makes PWS Unnecessary
content: If there were a non-circular way of characterizing which properties are essential to individuals, counterpart theory would become unnecessary for modal analysis.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Modal Realism Requires Retrograde Space-Time Conceptions
content: David Lewis's PWS-based analysis of counterfactuals succeeds only if we accept philosophically retrograde conceptions of space and time.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Counterfactuals and Causation Cannot Be Separated
content: Counterfactual conditionals cannot be analyzed independently of causation; attempts to analyze causation in terms of counterfactuals (or vice versa) are circular.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Similarity Metrics for Worlds Are Arbitrary Without Causation
content: Without invoking causal structure, any similarity metric used to compare possible worlds for counterfactual analysis becomes arbitrary and unintuitive.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Modal Questions About Worlds Are Substantive
content: Given truisms about spatiotemporal existence, it's a substantive modal question whether the worlds needed for PWS are even possible—a question PWS cannot answer without circularity.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Modality as Internal Structural Properties
content: A proposition's being necessarily true consists in its having certain internal structural properties; truth in all possible worlds is merely a symptom, not the essence, of necessity.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Lewis's Recombination Principle Supports Structural View
content: David Lewis's own account of modal epistemology (his 'principle of recombination') ironically supports the view that modality consists in structural properties rather than truth across worlds.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Factualist analysis of counterfactuals fails
content: The factualist (possible worlds) analysis of counterfactuals is untenable. It requires metaphysically possible worlds with same laws but different facts, which is typically logically impossible. In deterministic worlds, any single event difference requires massive past differences. In indeterministic worlds, counterfactuals lose their truth conditions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Possible worlds analysis requires circular mixture of determinism
content: The factualist analysis requires different counterfactuals to be validated by different mixtures of determinism and indeterminism. But all counterfactuals must be evaluated relative to the same world with the same laws. This requires our world to simultaneously exhibit incompatible mixtures of determinism and indeterminism, which is absurd.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Indeterminism destroys counterfactual truth conditions
content: If the macroscopic world is non-negligibly indeterministic, the factualist position is nullified. If identical initial conditions lead to an outcome only X% of the time, then the counterfactual 'if I'd turned the key, the car would have started' lacks truth value - at most we can say there's an X% chance it starts.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Worlds are not sets of propositions
content: Worlds are not sets of propositions. Our world is something which makes propositions be true or false. A set of propositions does not make propositions be true or false. The set <snow is white, grass is green, penguins fly> doesn't make any of those propositions true or false - it exists regardless of their truth values.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Weak factualism is incoherent
content: Weak factualists (who identify worlds with sets of propositions) hold an incoherent position. They deny that counterfactuals merely register probabilification relations among propositions, and they deny that counterfactuals register facts about other concrete worlds. But these are the only coherent options.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Maximal consistent sets useless for counterfactuals
content: Alternative worlds as maximal consistent sets of propositions are absolutely useless for analyzing counterfactuals. Such sets would need to contain propositions covering every possible question, but including all such detail defeats the purpose of counterfactual analysis.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Philosophy as Pathological Symptom Rather Than Pure Inquiry
content: Philosophy, at least in its skeptical and hyper-rationalist forms, is better understood as a pathological symptom analogous to OCD rather than as pure disinterested inquiry into truth.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Paradigm-Relativism as Psychopathic Magnet
content: Concepts like Kuhn's 'paradigm' from The Structure of Scientific Revolutions, along with topics like time travel, quantum theory, relativism, and post-modernism, serve as magnets for truth-concealing psychopaths who swarm over these topics to dismantle life- and thought-critical epistemic instruments without putting anything in their place.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Refutation of Intentionalism Through Sellarsian Analysis
content: Unless Sellars is completely wrong about the myth of the given, intentionalism must be completely wrong. Since Sellars' anti-foundationalism is now widely accepted and his arguments are compelling, intentionalism should be rejected. The paper merely makes explicit the connection between intentionalism and foundationalism.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Translation of Linguistic Work for Philosophical Audiences
content: Boguslawski's paper, originally written for linguists, needs translation into the language of philosophy of language for philosophers to understand its relevance to their work. Such translation is not strict - it legitimately involves extending and modifying arguments and contentions for philosophical purposes.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: De-psychologizing Kant's Transcendental Arguments
content: Despite problems with synthetic a priori, Kant's important claims about causality, personal identity, and rationality are correct and founded on cogent arguments. But to make this apparent, Kant's reasoning must be 'de-psychologized' - statements about psychology reinterpreted as statements about logic. This requires only minor terminological adjustments (replacing 'synthetic a priori' with 'hard analytic').
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Market Regulation Necessity Thesis
content: Financial markets require government regulation to prevent systemic instability. Unregulated financial markets reliably produce crashes that harm the broader economy.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Systemic Risk Justifies Constraint
content: When private economic activities create systemic risks that endanger the broader economy, government intervention is justified to constrain those activities, even when individual actors are behaving rationally.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Separation of Function Principle
content: Institutions serving essential public functions (like holding customer deposits) should be legally separated from speculative activities to prevent public harm from private risk-taking.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Transparency as Regulatory Foundation
content: Market participants must operate with complete transparency to prevent fraud and enable informed decision-making. Opacity in financial markets enables exploitation and systemic instability.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Too-Big-To-Fail Paradox
content: When financial institutions become so large that their failure would catastrophically damage the economy, they must be either regulated more stringently or broken up. Their size creates moral hazard: they can take excessive risks knowing government must rescue them.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The State is Necessary for Contract Enforcement and Economies of Scale
content: Contrary to anarchist positions like Goldman's, the state is necessary for enforcing contracts and enabling economies of scale, which are in turn necessary for the improvements to life that people actually want and value.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Anarchism Fails on Pragmatic Grounds
content: While Goldman may be right that the state causes some crime and often behaves unjustly, anarchism fails because without state enforcement of contracts and provision of public goods, people cannot achieve the standard of living and freedom they desire. The benefits of the state outweigh its costs.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Primitivism/Tribalism Fails on Pragmatic Grounds
content: Rousseau's vision of pre-civilizational tribal life as ideal fails because tribal life involves serious disadvantages: lack of choices in profession and lifestyle, lack of medical care and education, geographical confinement, lack of technology, and need to work for every meal. These disadvantages outweigh any advantages of simpler social organization.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Tribal Life Was Not Idyllic
content: Contrary to Rousseau's romanticization, tribal life was likely not placid and carefree. Tribes attacked one another and were capable of behaving cruelly toward their own members. The evidence does not support the claim that pre-civilizational life was psychologically or morally superior.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Revealed Preference Argument Against Primitivism
content: If tribal life were truly idyllic as Rousseau claims, people today would opt for it, but they don't. This revealed preference is evidence against the claim that pre-civilizational life is superior.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Classical Liberalism is Probably Approximately Correct
content: Hayek's liberalism - the position that good government is minimal government that protects people, gives them freedom, but otherwise doesn't interfere - is likely at least approximately correct. Over-regulated economies fail (Soviet Union) and minimally regulated ones flourish (early US), and people should be allowed to live as they want within reason.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Competition is Superior to Central Planning
content: Following Hayek, competition is superior to central planning not only because it's more efficient, but because it's the only method that doesn't require coercive or arbitrary intervention by authority. Competition allows individuals to decide for themselves whether the prospects of an occupation compensate for its disadvantages.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: 'Intentions of the Framers' Denotes Idealization Not Empirical Reality
content: When we speak of 'the intentions of the framers', we are committed to an idealization rather than empirical actuality. The various framers (Adams, Jefferson, Washington) had numerically and qualitatively different minds, so talk of their collective intentions is institutional rather than psychological.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Originalism Involves Vicious Circularity
content: Originalism collapses into circularity (or triviality): Constitutional interpretations are to be evaluated in terms of framers' intentions, but the framers' intentions are to be understood in terms of the historical and social role of Constitutional interpretation.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Framers' Intentions as Theoretical Constructs Presupposing Conceptions of Constitutionality
content: The expression 'intentions of the framers' denotes an idealization—a theoretical construct with no precise spatiotemporal counterpart. The theories embodied in uses of this expression concern the role the Constitution should have, so originalism is viciously circular or trivial.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Counterfactuals About Framers Presuppose Rather Than Ground Constitutional Interpretations
content: When legal theorists run counterfactuals about what Jefferson would have said about contemporary issues (like gay marriage), they are not making empirical statements but a priori propositions about what he should have said given his values. This presupposes rather than grounds conceptions of Constitutionality.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Idealized Jefferson Incorporates Normative Commitments About Constitutionality
content: When we talk about 'what Jefferson would have said', we're talking about what some idealization of Jefferson would have said—a Jefferson purged of cultural limitations and temporal parochialism. This idealization incorporates a certain conception of Constitutionality.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: 'Jefferson's Values' Denotes Idealization Creating Parallel Circularity
content: The expression 'Jefferson's values' itself denotes an idealization rather than psychological reality, involving a circularity parallel to that in 'framers' intentions'. We use conceptions of Constitutionality to identify which values are 'his', then use those values to determine Constitutionality.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Historical Counterfactuals Replace Empirical Propositions with A Priori Propositions About Values
content: Once we start dealing with idealizations of framers' psyches rather than their actual psyches, we have replaced empirical propositions about their psychology with a priori propositions about values. Such counterfactuals presuppose conceptions of Constitutionality and thus cannot substantiate them.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Originalism Condemns Itself to Vicious Circularity or Innocuous Tautology
content: The originalist position, when properly understood, collapses into either vicious circularity (using Constitutional conceptions to identify framers' intentions/values, then using those to determine Constitutional meaning) or innocuous tautology (the Constitution means what we think it should mean).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Originalist Must Identify Values Before Running Counterfactuals, Creating Circle
content: The originalist is caught in a vicious circle: he must use counterfactuals to identify the values on which his conception of Constitutionality is based, but cannot run those counterfactuals until he has identified those values.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Free Markets Inherently Generate Irresolvable Wealth Inequalities
content: It is inherent in the free market that it leads to inequalities of wealth and income that cannot be resolved within a free market framework. The free market cannot be expected to diminish the wealth disparities that it itself creates.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Government Has Responsibility to Correct Market-Generated Inequalities
content: Since the free market cannot diminish the wealth disparities it creates, the government is responsible for diminishing these disparities. Capitalist countries like Sweden enjoy capitalism's benefits while avoiding unjust wealth disparities through progressive taxation.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: War on Drugs Vindicated Libertarian Conception of State's Rightful Role
content: Marijuana legalization constitutes a major victory for the libertarian conception of the state's rightful role. The state should confine itself to preventing clear crimes (assault, rape, theft, fraud) and should refrain from criminalizing acts for purely moral rather than pragmatic reasons.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Classical Liberals Vindicated on Drug Policy, Contemporary Liberals Proven Wrong
content: Right-wing economists (free-marketeers like Milton Friedman) were completely vindicated on drug policy: anti-drug laws paralyzed markets, encouraged cartels, depleted economy. Left-wing economists favoring government-created jobs were proven completely wrong.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Free Market as Driving Force of Healthy Economy and Culture
content: For classical liberals (Smith, Locke, Hume), ego/individualism is the driving force of a healthy economy, and a healthy economy is the backbone of a healthy culture. Freedom, including economic freedom, is the most natural condition possible.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Rousseau/Marx View Free Market as Basis of Unnatural Unjust Social Order
content: Opponents of free markets (Rousseau, Marx) regard it as basis of unnatural social order creating horrible inequalities and intolerable deprivations. What classical liberals see as healthy individualism, they see as psychopathic egoism and greed requiring return to pre-capitalist moral purity.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Plato's Justice Requires Rigid Hierarchical Social Strata Based on Fixed Nature
content: For Plato, justice is identical with people staying in their 'rightful place.' Social position should be determined by one's nature, which cannot relevantly change. Social strata must be rigidly defined with virtually impenetrable barriers between classes.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Plato's Republic Requires Complete Subordination of Private Life to State
content: Plato doesn't acknowledge legitimacy of private life. Entirety of person's life must be subordinate to state interests. Marriages arranged for state benefit, reproduction controlled, no private property, complete collectivization of existence.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Plato's Justice Completely Depends on State Propaganda and Systematic Lies
content: For Plato, justice depends completely on the state constantly lying to its citizenry, keeping them ignorant, and filling knowledge gaps with carefully constructed propaganda. This is necessary to maintain rigid hierarchical social order.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Plato's Distinction Between Benign and Dangerous Lies Cannot Be Sustained
content: Plato's distinction between benign/beneficial lies and improper/dangerous lies cannot be sustained. Since Plato's conception of justice denies people any freedoms, and such conception is false and evil, any lies told to uphold it are ipso facto evil.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Market Economy is Enlightenment Economy Linking Status to Ability Not Birth
content: Since the Enlightenment, one's stature in society has come to depend increasingly on one's own abilities (including intellectual abilities) and decreasingly on social position one was born into. Market economy is Enlightenment/post-Enlightenment economy where ability to acquire/retain property depends largely on intellectual abilities.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Kant's Enlightenment Autonomy Has Operational Meaning Only in Market Economy
content: Kant's exhortation to 'have the courage to use your own understanding' has operational meaning only in market economy. In non-market economy it's meaningless - indentured servant who thinks for himself gains nothing practical. But in market economy one has nothing to rely on but own judgment.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Legal Freedom Compatible with Complete Substantive Enslavement
content: The freedoms people have in market economy (to own and exchange goods and services) inevitably lead to complete mutual enslavement under pretexts of 'universal legal protection of rights' and 'economic freedom.' Legal freedom coexists with substantive slavery.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Free Market Turns People Into Commodities and Mere Spectacles
content: Market-based society, as opposed to culture-based society, inevitably turns people into objects or 'mere spectacles' (Debord's term). Pornography is paradigm case: human being literally turned into commodity that exists only to be consumed by being looked at.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: 2008 crisis was dual: housing bubble plus banking collapse
content: The 2008 financial crisis had two distinct components with different mechanisms: (1) a housing bubble driven by subprime lending and securitization, and (2) a banking system collapse caused by interconnected megabanks' exposure to toxic assets. These require different regulatory responses: the first needs better lending standards, the second needs to break up megabanks.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Socrates executed for wartime disruption, not truth-seeking
content: Socrates was executed for being disruptive during Athens' civil war, not for seeking truth. He caused Athenians to question moral beliefs that undergirded patriotism precisely when Athens most needed political unity.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Philosophical questioning can undermine necessary political unity
content: While truth is generally preferable to fiction, philosophical questioning of foundational beliefs can weaken necessary social cohesion, especially during crises requiring unified action.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Socrates sought power through intellectual influence
content: Socrates' philosophical activity was a strategy to gain power not through official positions but by installing his worldview at the top through grooming power-adjacent elites. He wanted to be the state, not serve it.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Philosopher-king doctrine as mission statement, not abstract ideal
content: The philosopher-king doctrine was not an abstract ideal but Socrates' mission statement - a concrete plan for installing someone like himself in power. That's why he was executed: his answers, if acted on, would have made him king.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Socrates delegitimized authority with replacement theory
content: Socrates wasn't just exposing ignorance for sport - he was methodically delegitimizing existing authority while building a replacement system where 'someone who knows' (the philosopher) should rule instead of generals, priests, or wealthy.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The Republic as conservative propaganda disguised as political philosophy
content: Plato's Republic is fundamentally conservative propaganda designed to rationalize aristocratic power and prevent revolution, not genuine political philosophy seeking justice.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Plato's Good/Real equivalence as coded social stability doctrine
content: Plato's linking of 'the Good' with 'the real' makes no literal sense (since bad things are real) but makes perfect sense as code: 'good/real' = what conduces to social stability, 'bad/shadows' = what threatens social stability.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Plato's political philosophy replaces world with thought-world
content: Plato's system was completely a priori - he wasn't engaging actual world but proposing to replace it with his own thought-world having little reality or justification outside his thought-space.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Philosopher-king doctrine is incoherent
content: The idea that society should be ruled by philosopher-king is incoherent because societies must be run by sapient doers, not sapient thinkers - by people who engage world through action, not by those who flee into intellectual constructions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Marx's political philosophy as destructive a priori fantasy
content: Marx explicitly proposed destroying existing social structure and replacing it with system having no real basis in reality (totally fabricated), which when implemented led to unprecedented loss of life and opportunity.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Cancelability Test
content: Conversational implicatures always cancelable. Existence presuppositions not cancelable. Therefore not conversational implicature.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Conventional Implicature Constraint
content: Conventional implicature doesn't obscure truth-conditions. Adds 'tone' but never makes synonyms differ in truth-conditions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Function of 'Exactly,' 'Precisely,' 'Literally' Modifiers
content: Expressions like 'exactly,' 'precisely,' and 'literally' have the semantic function of confining the auditor's attention to literal meaning - telling the auditor not to draw inferences beyond what is literally affirmed. These modifiers reveal what expressions mean literally by blocking pragmatic enrichment.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Group Psychology is Explanatorily Prior to Individual Psychology
content: Contrary to standard psychological methodology, group psychology should be understood as explanatorily fundamental, with individual psychology being derivative. Individual drives and behaviors are best explained as necessary for the survival and functioning of collectives, rather than collectives being aggregations of individual behaviors.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Conformism Cannot Be Explained by Individual Psychology Alone
content: The extreme degree of conformism exhibited by people - their deference to convention, custom, and fleeting fads even at the expense of personal gratification - cannot be adequately explained by individual psychology even after accounting for intellectual shortcomings and fear of others.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Collective Intelligence Exceeds Individual Intelligence
content: Given how unintelligent, ignorant, and lacking in moral fiber most individuals are, yet how much intelligence, knowledge, and moral rigor is embodied in collective behaviors (corporations, academic disciplines), it is implausible that collectives are mere aggregations of individuals pursuing their own paths. The collective appears to be the primary thing biologically.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Philosophers and Obsessive-Compulsives Share Compulsive Doubt
content: Philosophers and obsessive-compulsives are both compulsive doubters who doubt the obvious, rationalizing this as rigor while actually expressing impotence and fear of engaging the world.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Philosophers and OCD Sufferers Manipulate Symbolic Proxies Instead of Reality
content: Both philosophers and obsessive-compulsives deal with linguistic and symbolic proxies of reality rather than engaging the world directly, seeking dominance in the sphere of thought where they have power.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Preoccupation with Logical Niceties Derives from Impotence
content: Both philosophers and obsessive-compulsives are unduly preoccupied with logical niceties and fine points of argumentation as a derivative of their sense of impotence and lack of material to work on.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Mental Illness is Contextual; Physical Illness is Not
