content: Mental illnesses are contextual in nature—being an asset in some contexts and a liability in others—while physical illnesses like asthma, lupus, or cancer are simply liabilities in all contexts.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Mental Illness Serves Defensive Function
content: Mental illnesses serve a defensive/protective function, insulating the subject in a psychological 'safe-space' from toxic and threatening environments, even though they are dysfunctional in some respects.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Mental Illness Involves Misdeployed Strengths
content: Some mental illnesses involve misdeployed strengths of intellect and character—OCD involves misdeployed intelligence and focus; schizophrenia involves misdeployed creativity and emotional sensitivity.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Psychiatric Munchausen's by Proxy as Covert Child Abuse
content: Parents (usually mothers) get psychiatrists to falsely diagnose their children with autism, Asperger's, ADHD to gain attention, resulting in covert child murder through damaging over-attention from educational and psychiatric bureaucrats.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: OCD is Ultimately Voluntary
content: OCD is ultimately a voluntary condition and an affliction of the will. If one chooses to leave the defensive bubble and re-engage the world, OCD becomes irrelevant or assumes benign/productive forms.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: OCD Prognosis Depends on Volitional Choice
content: The prognosis for OCD is 100% positive if seen as ultimately voluntary, but negative if seen as garden-variety pathology outside the scope of will. OCD is eliminated or made adaptive by exercising will in growth-oriented ways.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Auto-hypnosis is Essential for Action
content: Auto-hypnosis (giving oneself commands whose efficacy doesn't depend on conscious judgment) is essential for action. Without it, one would be the ultimate bureaucrat who never does anything requiring sustained enthusiasm.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Psychopathy as Complete Lack of Integrity
content: Psychopathy is fundamentally defined as a complete lack of integrity, rather than by specific behavioral symptoms or clinical criteria.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Early-Onset Psychopathy: Failure to Develop Character Architecture
content: Early-onset psychopaths never develop the character-architecture of normal persons; any appearance of such architecture is pure fabrication. These individuals become con-artists, grifters, drifters, and cult-leaders.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Bureaucratic Psychopathy: Late-Onset Institutional Submission
content: A vastly more common form of psychopathy is 'bureaucratic psychopathy' (bureaupath), in which individuals forfeit their integrity late in life to fit into bureaucratic institutions or pseudo-legitimate professional areas like academia or law. These individuals retain the formal properties of normal character but have become hollow husks in whom 'the magic is gone and the spark is gone.'
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Academic Humanities Psychopathy: Truth-Concealing Through Pseudo-Cognitive Categories
content: A third type of late-onset psychopathy, prevalent in humanities academia, involves projecting one's failure to understand onto the object of non-understanding by 'sliming it up' with spongiform pseudo-cognitive categories like 'narrative,' 'critique,' and 'literature' rather than admitting non-comprehension.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Basic Tenet of Attachment Theory
content: A person's emotional attachments influence the way in which he deals with problematic situations, and the way in which he deals with problematic situations influences his relations to others. Attachment Theory is a cluster of theories based on this fundamental tenet.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Freud's Account of Character Architecture
content: According to Freud, a psychologically healthy adult is someone whose parents loved him but did not spoil him. The mother's job is to provide love (leading to self-love), and the father's job is to provide discipline (leading to self-discipline). Adult success depends on having a healthy combination of self-love and self-discipline.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Bowlby's Attachment Behavioral System
content: An 'attachment behavioral system' (ABS) refers to the behaviors and attitudes that determine how a person forms relationships and deals with abandonment. A person's ABS is largely determined by the nature of early-life relationships with caregivers. To become a healthy adult, a child needs at least one stable attachment with a caregiver.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Four Basic Infant Attachment Patterns
content: There are four basic attachment patterns in infants: (1) Secure - happy, confident, boldly exploratory with nurturing caregivers; (2) Anxious-ambivalent - cautious, worried about caregiver departure, with withdrawn/unreliable caregivers; (3) Anxious-avoidant - not distressed by departure, avoid caregiver on return, focus on physical environment, have abusive caregivers; (4) Disorganized - respond with fear to returning caregivers, have extremely abusive or highly unreliable caregivers.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Persistence of Attachment Patterns Through Development
content: The four attachment patterns (secure, anxious-ambivalent, anxious-avoidant, disorganized) persist from infancy through childhood into adulthood, though with developmentally appropriate manifestations. There is good evidence that a child's attachment pattern tends to be identical with the one he had as an infant, though categorical identity remains an open question. Some evidence suggests adults can have different attachment patterns from earlier life.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Attachment Insecurities Linked to Specific Psychopathologies
content: Attachment insecurities of both anxious and avoidant varieties are associated with depression, anxiety disorders, OCD, PTSD, suicidal tendencies, and eating disorders. Anxious attachment specifically associates with dependent, histrionic, and borderline disorders, while avoidant attachment associates with schizoid and avoidant disorders.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Kuczynski's Explanation of Attachment-Psychopathology Connections
content: According to Kuczynski (2012), schizoid and psychotic disorders involve scrambling of the subject's grasp of reality itself because early-life attachments were negative (not merely ambiguous), disposing them to flee from reality in the most radical way possible. By contrast, histrionic, borderline, and dependent disorders involve fundamentally non-delusive grasp of reality but inappropriate emotions because early-life attachments were ambivalent, disposing them to keep distance from external reality without altogether abandoning it.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Republic exhibits OCD-like rigidity and protocols
content: The absurdity of Plato's Republic manifests in its OCD-like features: rigid society, stereotyped protocols for education and social interaction, death penalty for minor violations (in Laws).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: OCD essence is ambivalence
content: The essence of OCD is ambivalence - simultaneously loving and hating the same object. The compulsively doting son both loves and hates his mother. Because he loves her, his desire not to be with her must express itself circuitously through compulsive behaviors.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Doing and undoing in OCD
content: The obsessional engages in 'doing and undoing' (Freud) - does something, then undoes it, then undoes the undoing. Driving to mother's house, then turning back for wallet, then back again for stove. This represents the stalemate between love and hatred, with each emotion expressing itself through the oscillating behavior.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: OCD behavior as overdetermined
content: OCD behaviors are overdetermined (Freud) - they serve multiple unconscious functions simultaneously. Back-and-forth driving serves both to express ambivalence toward mother and to discharge sexual frustration through piston-like repetitive motion mimicking the sexual act.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Symbolic representation in OCD symptoms
content: OCD symptoms involve symbolic representation of unconscious desires and conflicts. Fear about stove being left on represents undischarged libido; the stove symbolizes passionate desire. Driving behavior symbolizes sexual act. 'Fear' the stove will explode is really desire that genital region will 'explode.'
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Awareness without consciousness in the obsessional
content: The obsessional is aware of underlying dynamics (mother's treachery, sexual frustration) without being consciously aware. One can be aware of something at the level of unconsciousness. The person doesn't quite see irritating behaviors for what they are even unconsciously, but is surely aware at some level.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Single ultimate determinant despite overdetermination
content: Despite overdetermination, behavior may have a single ultimate determinant. The son's behavior is overdetermined by both ambivalence toward mother and sexual frustration, but ultimately the sexual frustration is primary - ambivalence exists because mother causes sexual frustration. The two causes operate as a single cause in this context.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Consciousness of hatred eliminates compulsions
content: When unconscious hatred becomes conscious, associated compulsions vanish. The compulsiveness exists precisely because the true feelings are unconscious. Once awareness reaches consciousness, the need for disguised expression through compulsion disappears.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Compulsive time management as defense
content: Compulsive punctuality (showing up two hours early) serves as a hedge against the unconscious wish not to show up at all. Being 'hyper on time' insulates against the desire to avoid the obligation entirely. This is another form of doing and undoing.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Problem Portability
content: Wherever you go, there you are. Your problems tend to follow you. External change without internal change doesn't solve problems.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Universal Beauty Under Blindness
content: Everything is beautiful, but most people are blind to most of the beauty. The ugliness perceived in the world reflects perceptual limitations rather than absence of beauty.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Ability-Demand Asymmetry
content: Ability will never catch up with the demand for it. There is always more need for ability than supply of it.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: God progressed to divinity from humanity
content: Joseph Smith's King Follett Discourse argued that God was once a man who became divine through spiritual development. This represents a radical break from traditional Christian theology, implying divinity is not an absolute status but an achieved state, and the distinction between God and humanity is one of degree rather than kind.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: God created through organization, not ex nihilo
content: God did not create the world ex nihilo but by organizing pre-existing chaotic matter. The Hebrew 'baurau' means to organize, not to create from nothing. Pure elements are eternal and indestructible—they can be organized and reorganized but never created or destroyed.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Human spirits are immortal and have always existed
content: The intelligence of human spirits has no beginning and no end. If something is immortal (has no end), logic dictates it also had no beginning. Therefore, human beings have always existed eternally. This eternal pre-existence follows from the same principle that makes God self-existent.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Multiple gods exist in hierarchical arrangement
content: Although there is a supreme God, multiple lesser gods also exist. This follows from the doctrine of eternal progression: if humans can become gods through spiritual development, and this process has been ongoing eternally, then many gods must exist. The Hebrew 'Elohim' (Gods, plural) indicates this plurality.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: King Follett vision transcends its arguments
content: Smith's arguments for his theological positions in KFD, even if assumed cogent, would not lead anyone to accept his radical vision. The merits of the vision lie in the vision itself, not in the arguments. This raises the historiographical question: where did Smith's vision originate?
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Smith's theology evolved from monotheism to polytheism
content: Joseph Smith's theology underwent systematic evolution. Early period (1820-1835): unambiguous monotheism. Middle period (1835): God and Jesus treated as distinct entities. Later Nauvoo period (1839-1844): full polytheism—God has a father, belongs to a council of gods, humans can become gods. Hebrew study accelerated the shift.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Orthodox Christianity is crypto-polytheistic
content: Orthodox Christianity is not strictly monotheistic despite its claims. If Jesus is truly the son of God (not God himself), and the Holy Ghost is a distinct force, and God is an exalted person-like being, then there are at least three divine beings, making Christianity crypto-polytheistic. The doctrine that God, Jesus, and Holy Ghost are 'three but one' is absurd and logically incoherent.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Christianity represents revival of polytheistic instincts
content: Historically, polytheism is the rule and monotheism the exception. Christianity may represent a revival of polytheistic instincts. Early Church Doctors needed at least two divinities (God and Jesus) but couldn't openly embrace polytheism. They therefore affirmed absurdly that God and Jesus, though two, are one.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Smith's theology prioritizes divine-human relationship
content: Smith's fundamental question was: What must God be like if humans are to have the required relationship with Him? This breaks with both philosophical and Christian traditions that focus on logical puzzles about God's attributes. Smith starts with the assumption that God is psychologically able and willing to serve as guardian, attributing only as much power and knowledge as is compatible with this relational requirement.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Logical proofs of God turn Him into impersonal force
content: Attempts to prove God's existence inevitably turn Him into an impersonal force or principle, stripping Him of the ability to have relationships with humans. If 'God' is defined as 'maximally perfect being,' 'guarantor of natural law,' or 'unmoved mover,' this abstracts away the personal characteristics necessary for divine-human relationship.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Three Attitudes Toward Religion
content: There are fundamentally three attitudes toward religion: (1) uncritical acceptance, (2) rejection, and (3) critical/reflective acceptance.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Contemporary Fundamentalism is Reactive, Not Uncritical
content: Contemporary religious fundamentalists are not genuinely 'uncritically accepting' of religion because they live in pluralistic societies and are reacting against non-religious views.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Contemporary Atheism as Herd Mentality
content: Most contemporary atheists are simply following social norms rather than reasoning independently, making their mentality similar to medieval religious believers.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Reductive vs. Non-Reductive Accounts of Religion
content: There are both reductive (explanatory/causal) and non-reductive (phenomenological/essential) truths about religion, and the essence of religion lies in non-reductive truths.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Religion Requires Unshakable Conviction in Transcendence
content: The essence of religious sentiment is the unshakable conviction that 'this world is not all that there is' and that psychological health requires this view.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Writing as the Basis of Rationalism
content: The development of writing is the foundation of rationalism, creating economies of scale and enabling the linearization of time.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Economies of Scale Cause Time-Linearization
content: Large-scale economic and social organization causes the shift from circular to linear conceptions of time characteristic of rationalism.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: James, Otto, and Eliade Describe Animism, Not Institutional Religion
content: When James, Otto, and Eliade discuss 'religion,' they are actually describing pre-civilizational animistic spiritualism, not institutional religions like Christianity or Islam.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Spiritualism vs. Rationalism as Fundamental Orientations
content: For the spiritualist, the world is a living subject and partner; for the rationalist, the world is dead matter existing only to be used as an object.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Humans Cannot Become Non-Spiritual
content: Just as we cannot become asexual (per Freud), we cannot become non-spiritual; we can only mistakenly believe we are non-spiritual and thereby undermine our biological condition.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Rationalism as Extension of Spiritualism, Not Rejection
content: Rationalism is a 'rarefied extension' of spiritualism, not a rejection of it; the error is seeing rationalism as anti-spiritual.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Contemporary 'Spiritualism' is Actually Nihilism
content: 21st-century self-described 'spiritual but not religious' people manifest nihilism and absence of genuine spiritualism, not its presence.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Omniscience precludes action
content: An all-knowing being cannot act because action presupposes ignorance. If one knows with certainty what will happen, one cannot coherently attempt to influence what will happen and therefore cannot intend to act.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Omnipotence precludes feeling
content: An all-powerful being cannot experience feelings. Only a being capable of being changed can experience feelings, and if a being is incapable of being changed, it cannot feel.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Immutability precludes self-change
content: A being incapable of being changed cannot change itself. To change oneself is to be changed, albeit by oneself. A being that cannot be changed cannot be changed by anything, including itself.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Omnipotence entails impotence
content: If a being is all-powerful (omnipotent), it is completely impotent. The concept of an all-powerful being is incoherent because such a being could neither act nor change.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Traditional divine attributes are incoherent
content: The concepts of an all-knowing being and an all-powerful being are both incoherent. To the extent we conceptualize God as all-knowing and all-powerful, we are conceptualizing Him incoherently.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Consciousness is inherent in existence itself
content: It is inherent in existence that existence be conscious. The universe is disintegrating (lacking consciousness) only to the extent it is ceasing to be what it is. To the extent the universe is growing and becoming what it truly is, it has consciousness. Therefore, there is ipso facto a God - the universe itself, which is pulsating with life and thought rather than being cold and mechanical.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Confirmation Requires Principled Generalizations
content: Only principled (nomic/causal) generalizations, not accidental generalizations, can be confirmed. When 'All ravens are black' is read as a principled generalization, it has nomic content and is not equivalent to 'All non-black things are non-ravens.'
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI Systems Test Philosophical Theories Empirically
content: Philosophical theories about reasoning, knowledge acquisition, scientific discovery can be empirically tested by examining whether successful AI systems operate according to those theories. AI provides concrete examinable implementations allowing theory adjudication.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Logic of Discovery is Possible
content: Contrary to traditional philosophy of science claiming logic of discovery is impossible, examining AI scientific reasoning reveals identifiable principles guiding successful theory generation. Genuine logic of discovery exists.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI Falsifies Popperian Falsificationism
content: AI's success in scientific discovery falsifies Popper's theory that science proceeds primarily through conjecture and refutation. AI systems generate successful theories through pattern matching and inductive generalization, not primarily through bold conjectures and attempts at falsification.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Inductive Discovery Precedes Deductive Testing
content: Contra Popper, successful scientific discovery requires inductive pattern recognition to generate plausible hypotheses before deductive testing. AI demonstrates that purely conjectural approaches without inductive guidance are ineffective.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Reverse Brain Engineering as Scientific Method
content: By building AI systems that replicate cognitive functions, we can infer the computational architecture necessary for those functions. This 'reverse engineering' of the brain through AI construction represents a new and powerful methodology in philosophy of science and cognitive science.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: AI Falsifies Deductive-Nomological Model of Explanation
content: AI's successful explanatory practices falsify the deductive-nomological (covering law) model of explanation. AI generates successful explanations through pattern recognition, analogy, and causal modeling that don't require deduction from universal laws.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Causal-Mechanistic Explanation Doesn't Require Universal Laws
content: AI demonstrates that causal-mechanistic explanation can be successful without appeal to universal laws. Understanding how something works doesn't require subsuming it under exceptionless generalizations.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Explanatory Understanding Through Pattern Recognition
content: AI reveals that explanatory understanding can be achieved through recognition of patterns and structural similarities rather than derivation from laws. This suggests explanation is more about grasping relevant relationships than deductive systematization.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Laws of Nature Not Confined to Actual Objects
content: The scope of natural law is not confined to actual or even possible objects. Many laws hold with respect to classes all of whose members are merely possible or even prohibited by other natural laws.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge of Imperceptibles Identical with Conditional Knowledge
content: Knowledge of the imperceptible is identical with knowledge of conditional truth. Knowledge of future, past, possible, and imperceptible present states is always conditional knowledge based on laws.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Three Kinds of Imperceptibles
content: Physical objects can be imperceptible in three ways: (1) imperceptible due to severed causal processes (objects in other rooms); (2) imperceptible due to size but perceptible with technology (cells, molecules); (3) imperceptible by natural law regardless of technology (photons, subatomic particles).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The Epistemic Function of Natural Law
content: Scientists aspire to identify natural laws so they can, when given context-specific information, make true statements about future, past, or possible behavior of contexts. Laws enable conditional prediction and explanation.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Science Prioritizes Principles Over Particular Facts
content: Any interest science has in a given particular fact is subordinate to its interest in the general principles in terms of which that fact is to be understood. Scientists study particular instances only insofar as they instantiate general laws.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Laws May Be Place and Time-Sensitive
content: Some natural laws are place- and time-sensitive rather than spatiotemporally invariant. Laws need not hold uniformly across all regions of space-time to be genuine laws.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Hume's Regularity Analysis of Causation Is False
content: Hume's Regularity Analysis - the view that causation is nothing but constant conjunction, that 'X causes Y' means 'events of type X are regularly followed by events of type Y' - is demonstrably false.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Hume-Worlds Observationally Different from Non-Humean Worlds
content: A Hume-world (where causation equals regularity with no underlying powers) would be observationally different from our world. The concept of a Hume-world cannot support Hume's analysis.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The Deductive-Nomological Model of Explanation Is False
content: The Deductive-Nomological (DN) model - which holds that to explain event E is to derive E from natural laws plus antecedent conditions - is fundamentally mistaken. Explanation requires causal knowledge, not merely law-subsumption.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: DN Viciously Circular via Counterfactual Support
content: The DN model is viciously circular if it requires laws to support counterfactuals (as Hempel proposes). Counterfactuals are cryptocausal statements; knowing them requires knowing causes; but knowing causes already provides explanations.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Causal Knowledge as Differential Knowledge
content: Causal knowledge is differential knowledge - knowledge of what varies with what. To know causes is to know which changes depend on which other changes and in what proportions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Causation as Proportionality Restoration
content: Causation is fundamentally proportionality restoration. Effects are proportional to their causes (threshold effects aside). When a force acts on an object, the resulting change is proportional to the force magnitude.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Physical Laws as Regularities of Proportion
content: Physical laws are regularities of proportion rather than simple universal generalizations. Laws describe how magnitudes vary proportionally with each other rather than stating that all Fs are Gs.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Knowledge-Why Equals High-Resolution Knowledge-What
content: To have knowledge-why is to have high-resolution knowledge-what. Explanatory knowledge differs from mere descriptive knowledge in degree of detail and specificity, not in kind.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The Raven Paradox a By-Product of Regularity Analysis
content: The Raven Paradox (that non-black non-ravens confirm 'all ravens are black') is an artifact of the Regularity Analysis of causation. Once causation is properly understood, the paradox dissolves.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Determinism Doesn't Entail Complete Predictability
content: Determinism (every event has a cause) does not entail complete predictability. Two reasons: (1) interference effects make prediction impossible without infinite precision, and (2) knowledge growth itself cannot be predicted.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Implementation-Indeterminism Distinguished from Program-Determinism
content: Program-determinism (software-level determinism) is compatible with implementation-indeterminism (hardware-level indeterminism). The same program can be implemented by different physical processes.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Truths Not Objects Are Objects of Explanation
content: Truths, not objects or states of affairs themselves, are the proper objects of explanation. We explain why propositions are true, not why objects exist (except derivatively).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Relativity Theory Reveals Causal Structure of Spacetime
content: Recognition that temporal order is causal was forced on us by empirical discoveries, particularly Relativity Theory. If events E and E* are such that no causal signal can pass between them, they have no determinate temporal order. But this recognition that temporal order is causal is itself less like an empirical statement ('all rhenates are chordates') than like a hard analytic truth ('triangles are regions bounded by three coplanar lines').
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Complete Description Entails Neighborhood Events
content: For an arbitrary event E, if D is a complete description of E, then D entails the occurrence of events that, by ordinary standards, are distinct from E. A correct and complete description of an empirical state of affairs permits deduction of events in its neighborhood because spatiotemporal continuity is causal.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Psychological Versus Physical Explanation Unified
content: Explanation always consists in showing logical and principled relation between initial and terminal conditions. There is no need to reduce psychology to statistics (Hempel, Mill) or to create artificial division between human and natural sciences (Dilthey). Psychological and physical explanation are fundamentally the same kind - both show why it makes sense that events occurred.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Explanation as Principled Relationship, Not Mere Regularity
content: Explanation exposes principled relationships, not mere regularities. Regularities express rather than constitute principled relationships. The existence of a regularity (e.g., flipping switch causes light to turn on) is consequence, not substance, of principled relationship among properties. If this is wrong, regularity becomes coincidence of unspeakable proportions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Logically equivalent statements are not necessarily confirmationally equivalent
content: Logically equivalent statements are not necessarily confirmationally equivalent
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Confirmation tracks nomic or causal content, not mere logical form
content: Confirmation tracks nomic or causal content, not mere logical form
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: 'All metal expands when heated' can be confirmed but not 'all objects in Smith's pocket expand when heated' (only principled generalizations confirmable)
content: 'All metal expands when heated' can be confirmed but not 'all objects in Smith's pocket expand when heated' (only principled generalizations confirmable)
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Philosophical resistance to neuroscience parallels historical science resistance
content: Philosophers' resistance to neuroscientific findings about consciousness and free will parallels historical examples of disciplines resisting scientific findings that threatened their authority (e.g., Catholic Church vs. heliocentrism, vitalists vs. mechanistic biology). In each case, defensive reactions disguised as methodological sophistication protected cherished beliefs.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Natural Laws and Modal Space
content: The relationship between natural laws and what's metaphysically possible is a substantive question that PWS presupposes rather than answers.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Laws cannot be defined except via counterfactuals
content: There is widespread agreement that the concept of a law of nature cannot be defined except in terms of counterfactuals - a law is inter alia something that supports counterfactuals. This creates circularity for the factualist analysis, which must understand counterfactuals in terms of laws.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Probability definable from actual events only
content: The relevant kind of probability can be defined wholly in terms of what has happened (not what would happen and not even what must happen in a nomic sense). This avoids the circularity problem in analyzing counterfactuals.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Critique of Humean analysis of laws
content: The Humean analysis of laws as regularities is viciously circular. If states of affairs are themselves causal processes (as they must be), then defining causation as regular concomitance of states of affairs is circular. Additionally, temporal succession itself appears to be a causal notion, making the analysis doubly circular.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Probability must be interpreted causally, not statistically
content: When we say the probability of an event is X%, this statement must be interpreted causally, not statistically. What is being said is that, given the laws of physics/nature and the construction of the system, it is a possibility (with degree X) that the event will occur, whether or not it ever actually occurs. Probability is determined by causal mechanisms and laws, not by observed frequencies.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Probability is causal, not statistical
content: When it is said that probability of a computer-malfunction is greater than 0%, the statement being made is to be interpreted CAUSALLY, not statistically. Probability is a function of laws and causal mechanisms, not observed frequencies.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Statistics are evidence of probabilities but not themselves probabilities
content: Statistics (observed frequencies) are evidence for what the probabilities are, but they are not identical with probabilities. The actual probability is determined by the underlying causal/nomic structure, and statistics can be misleading if they happen to diverge from that structure due to coincidence. Two worlds with identical laws have identical probabilities even if their statistics differ radically.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Statistics are evidence for probability, not identical with probability
content: Statistics are evidence of probabilities; statistics are not themselves probabilities. Frequency Theory (FT) wrongly identifies statistics with probability.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: The W1/W2 thought experiment refutes the Frequency Theory of Probability
content: Consider W1 and W2, two worlds with identical laws where computers have probability P of malfunctioning. In W1, the statistics match this probability. In W2, by sheer coincidence, no computer ever malfunctions (0% frequency). Frequency Theory says W2-probability = 0%, but this is false. The actual probability in both worlds is P (determined by the laws), even though the statistics differ. This refutes Frequency Theory.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: W1/W2 thought experiment refutes Frequency Theory
content: W1: laws say P(malfunction)=10%, statistics show 10%. W2: same laws, P(malfunction)=10%, but by coincidence statistics show 0%. Frequency Theory wrongly says P(W2)=0% but P(W1)=10%. Both actually have P=10% (determined by laws).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Probability remains constant even when statistics are misleading due to coincidence
content: In a world with the same biological laws as ours, but where by sheer coincidence smokers never get cancer, doctors would be wrong to say smoking is harmless. The probability that a smoker will get cancer in that world is the SAME as in our world, because the probability is determined by the biological laws (which are identical), not by the observed frequencies (which differ).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Smoking-cancer example refutes Frequency Theory
content: In a world with our biological laws but where by coincidence no smoker gets cancer, Frequency Theory says P(cancer|smoking)=0%. Wrong. P(cancer|smoking) = same as our world (determined by biological laws), regardless of coincidental statistics.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Worlds with identical laws have identical probabilities regardless of statistical divergences
content: If two worlds W1 and W2 have the same laws of nature, they have the same probabilistic structure - the same probabilities for all events - even if their actual statistical frequencies happen to diverge dramatically due to coincidence. Probability supervenes on laws/causal mechanisms, not on observed patterns.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Same laws entail same probabilities regardless of statistics
content: Worlds with identical laws of nature have identical probabilities, regardless of any statistical divergences caused by coincidence.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Worlds with different causal/nomic structures have different probabilities even if event-sequences are identical
content: If universe U1 is governed by laws while universe U2 is governed by pure chance (or different laws), then the probabilities of events in U1 and U2 are DIFFERENT, even if the actual sequence of events that occurs in each universe is identical. This is because probability is determined by the underlying causal/nomic structure, not by the pattern of events. U1's events have probabilities determined by laws; U2's events have probabilities determined by chance (or by different laws).
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Different causal/nomic structures entail different probabilities
content: If two universes have different causal/nomic structures (different laws), they have different probabilities, even if their event-sequences are observationally identical.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Minds ≠ Selves
content: Having a mind does not entail being a self. Co-corporeal, informationally integrated mental states = mind, but NOT sufficient for selfhood.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Selves Require Values
content: No values = no self (though may have mind). Values necessary for agency. No agency without selves.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Selfhood as Matter of Degree
content: Selfhood not binary but admits of degrees. Correlates with degree of value-structured architecture.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: PWS Creates Set-Theoretic Paradoxes
content: Identifying worlds with sets of propositions creates vicious circle problems analogous to classical set-theoretic paradoxes.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Freedom Has Intrinsic Value Within Reasonable Limits
content: People should, within reason, be allowed to live the way they want to live. Overly invasive governments prevent this and are therefore objectionable on that basis. The ability to choose one's own path in life has intrinsic value.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: One learns more from success than from failure (contra common wisdom)
content: One learns more from success than from failure (contra common wisdom)
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Each success opens up new and completely unforeseen vistas; each failure is nothing but a dead end from which nothing is learned
content: Each success opens up new and completely unforeseen vistas; each failure is nothing but a dead end from which nothing is learned
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: One learns from adversity, not from failure
content: One learns from adversity, not from failure
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Failure is the end-result of adversity that was not triumphed over; adversity and failure are distinct
content: Failure is the end-result of adversity that was not triumphed over; adversity and failure are distinct
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Everybody wants money, including those who claim to spurn it
content: Everybody wants money, including those who claim to spurn it
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Authentic religious sentiment does not require membership in an organized religion
content: Authentic religious sentiment does not require membership in an organized religion
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Authentic religious sentiment requires a personal relationship with the divine
content: Authentic religious sentiment requires a personal relationship with the divine
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Religious people believe life to be meaningful and are therefore relatively adversity-tolerant
content: Religious people believe life to be meaningful and are therefore relatively adversity-tolerant
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Religious sentiment makes people sane (when properly functioning)
content: Religious sentiment makes people sane (when properly functioning)
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Intrinsic Value and Self-Consolidation
content: Intrinsically valuable = what consolidates one's agency. Not hedonistic.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Instrumental vs Intrinsic Good
content: Goodness divides into instrumental good (useful for goals) and intrinsic good (good in itself). Ethics concerns intrinsic goodness.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Intrinsic Good vs Commendable
content: Intrinsic goodness and praiseworthiness are distinct. Some intrinsically good things are not praiseworthy.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Moral Responsibility Based on Intentions
content: Praise/blame depends on intended outcome, not actual outcome.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Against Emotivism
content: Moral judgments are not merely expressions of emotion. They are genuine assertions with truth-values.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Against Moral Relativism
content: Moral relativism is false. There are objective moral truths.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Against Kant's Categorical Imperative
content: Kant's categorical imperative fails as a criterion for right action.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Against Pure Hedonism
content: Pleasure is not the only intrinsic good. Hedonism is false.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Against Pure Utilitarianism
content: Act utilitarianism is false. It violates rights and permits obviously wrong actions.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Against Divine Command Theory
content: Morality is not based on God's commands. Euthyphro dilemma refutes divine command theory.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: We Cannot Choose Our Values
content: We cannot freely choose what we value. The idea of 'choosing one's own values' is incoherent.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Law Must Be Based on Justice
content: The purpose of law is to secure justice. Legal systems must be evaluated by whether they achieve justice.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Superior Person's Vigilant Stability
content: The superior person maintains stable, centered attitude while being appropriately responsive to changing circumstances. 'When resting in safety, does not forget danger may come. When secure, does not overlook possibility of ruin. When orderly, knows disorder may come. Therefore, when disaster strikes, is ready.'
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Judicious Speech as Virtue
content: The superior person is careful about what they say and how they say it; they do not speak loosely. Carefulness in speech reflects carefulness in thought and respect for words' consequences.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Practice-Preaching Unity
content: The superior person practices what they preach and either reconciles themselves to their situation or changes it. They are never idle.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Moral Courage as Essential Virtue
content: To know what you must do and still not do it shows lack of moral courage, which is the worst sin. Excellence requires moral courage, not merely will power.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski

paper_title: Earnest Striving Constitutes Achievement
content: If you earnestly try to be a superior person, you are, for that very reason, on your way to being such a person. The sincere attempt itself constitutes progress toward the goal.
author: J.-M. Kuczynski
